speaking.w: `` My child , what do you mean ? What is his age , I beg to know ! ''
`` It 's evident Daisy is n't out yet , ''
`` THE PICKWICK PORTFOLIO ''
`` Now then , vote again . Everybody remember it 's our Laurie , and say , ` Aye ! ' ''
`` Come now , do n't lay it all on yourself . You know I proposed the cupboard , ''
`` Votre Amie . ''
`` About your age , ''
`` She has had a good example before her all her life , my dear , ''
`` Well , he was a great man , and when he could n't have one sister he took the other , and was happy . ''
`` There is n't a bit of flirt in that girl , is there ? ''
`` She 's not a stricken deer anyway , ''
`` Oh , John , my dear , kind , hard-working boy . I did n't mean it ! It was so wicked , so untrue and ungrateful , how could I say it ! Oh , how could I say it ! ''
`` What for ? ''
`` Should n't ask you , if I did n't . ''
`` She 's right , the lad is lonely . I 'll see what these little girls can do for him , ''

`` The boy neglects his music now , and I 'm glad of it , for he was getting too fond of it . But the piano suffers for want of use . Would n't some of your girls like to run over , and practice on it now and then , just to keep it in tune , you know , ma'am ? ''

`` They need n't see or speak to anyone , but run in at any time . For I 'm shut up in my study at the other end of the house , Laurie is out a great deal , and the servants are never near the drawing room after nine o'clock . ''
`` I came to thank you , sir , for ... ''
`` Come in ! ''

`` That wo n't do . He shall not shelter himself behind a promise from you softhearted girls . If he 's done anything amiss , he shall confess , beg pardon , and be punished . Out with it , Jo . I wo n't be kept in the dark . ''
`` Hum ... ha ... well , if the boy held his tongue because he promised , and not from obstinacy , I 'll forgive him . He 's a stubborn fellow and hard to manage , ''
`` You hussy , how dare you talk in that way ? Where 's your respect for me , and your proper bringing up ? Bless the boys and girls ! What torments they are , yet we ca n't do without them , ''

`` If I were you , I 'd write him an apology , Sir . He says he wo n't come down till he has one , and talks about Washington , and goes on in an absurd way . A formal apology will make him see how foolish he is , and bring him down quite amiable . Try it . He likes fun , and this way is better than talking . I 'll carry it up , and teach him his duty . ''
`` Laurie , my lad , if you ever want to indulge in this sort of thing , get one of those little girls to help you , and I shall be perfectly satisfied , ''
`` That 's very fine , I dare say , but it 's sad enough to make one cry . Give us something gayer , lad , ''
`` Not quite . I want to say one thing , and then there shall be an end of it , ''
`` Jo can do it , and be happy in it . It 's a splendid idea . Tell us all about it , ''
`` Which would Mademoiselle choose if she had her will ? ''
`` I , too , covet that , but not as a necklace . Ah , no ! To me it is a rosary , and as such I should use it like a good catholic , ''

`` It would be excellent and charming , and I shall gladly arrange the little dressing room for you if you like it . Say nothing to Madame , but when she sleeps go you and sit alone a while to think good thoughts , and pray the dear God preserve your sister . ''
`` To you and your sisters . I know it , Madame confides in me . I witnessed her will , and it is to be so , ''
`` It 's no use ! Do the best you can when the time comes , and if the audience laughs , do n't blame me . Come on , Meg . ''
`` I told you so ! I told you so ! ''
`` Now , my dear , make yourself at home , ''

`` I 'm on the drive from morning to night , as you may suppose with such a family , but a great anxiety will be off my mind if I know the children are safe with you . My rooms are always open to you , and your own shall be as comfortable as I can make it . There are some pleasant people in the house if you feel sociable , and your evenings are always free . Come to me if anything goes wrong , and be as happy as you can . There 's the tea bell , I must run and change my cap . ''
`` I ca n't . I 'm not playing , I never do , ''
`` Talk to me , please . It 's dull , sitting by myself , ''
`` Well , I like to hear about cricket and boating and hunting , ''
`` I did once , but I can never hunt again , for I got hurt leaping a confounded five-barred gate , so there are no more horses and hounds for me , ''
`` Will you , please ? ''
`` Here 's your posy , Mother ! Laurie never forgets that , ''
`` I think you are right , there . You could do nothing at home , and it is a great comfort to them to know that you are well and happy , and enjoying so much , my dear . ''
`` Father , Mother , this is my friend , Professor Bhaer , ''
`` Yes , and she 's jolly and we like her lots , ''
`` We are playing nargerie , ''
`` Annie Moffat has blue and pink bows on her nightcaps . Would you put some on mine ? ''
`` It 's for Belle , of course , George always sends her some , but these are altogether ravishing , ''
`` Oh , indeed ! ''
`` It 's very nice of him to send you flowers , is n't it ? ''
`` I do n't choose . Please go away and let me be ! ''
`` The coolness of you two rascals is amazing , ''
`` Here 's a letter from the old gentleman ! Come quick , and read it ! ''
`` She could not think it he , ''
`` We have n't got Father , and shall not have him for a long time . ''
`` perhaps never , ''

`` But I do n't think the little we should spend would do any good . We 've each got a dollar , and the army would n't be much helped by our giving that . I agree not to expect anything from Mother or you , but I do want to buy _ Undine and Sintran _ for myself . I 've wanted it so long , ''
`` Mother did n't say anything about our money , and she wo n't wish us to give up everything . Let 's each buy what we want , and have a little fun ; I 'm sure we work hard enough to earn it , ''
`` You do n't have half such a hard time as I do , ''
`` If you mean libel , I 'd say so , and not talk about labels , as if Papa was a pickle bottle , ''
`` I 'm not ! And if turning up my hair makes me one , I 'll wear it in two tails till I 'm twenty , ''

`` I hate to think I 've got to grow up , and be Miss March , and wear long gowns , and look as prim as a China Aster ! It 's bad enough to be a girl , anyway , when I like boy 's games and work and manners ! I ca n't get over my disappointment in not being a boy . And it 's worse than ever now , for I 'm dying to go and fight with Papa . And I can only stay home and knit , like a poky old woman ! ''
`` I 'm the man of the family now Papa is away , and I shall provide the slippers , for he told me to take special care of Mother while he was gone . ''
`` That 's like you , dear ! What will we get ? ''
`` Army shoes , best to be had , ''
`` Put them on the table , and bring her in and see her open the bundles . Do n't you remember how we used to do on our birthdays ? ''
`` Let Marmee think we are getting things for ourselves , and then surprise her . We must go shopping tomorrow afternoon , Meg . There is so much to do about the play for Christmas night , ''

`` You wo n't stop , I know , as long as you can trail round in a white gown with your hair down , and wear gold-paper jewelry . You are the best actress we 've got , and there 'll be an end of everything if you quit the boards , ''
`` Do it this way . Clasp your hands so , and stagger across the room , crying frantically , ` Roderigo ! Save me ! Save me ! ' ''
`` Not quite , ''

`` I do think _ The Witches Curse , an Operatic Tragedy _ is rather a nice thing , but I 'd like to try _ Macbeth _ , if we only had a trapdoor for Banquo . I always wanted to do the killing part . ` Is that a dagger that I see before me ? ''
`` A letter ! A letter ! Three cheers for Father ! ''

`` Yes , a nice long letter . He is well , and thinks he shall get through the cold season better than we feared . He sends all sorts of loving wishes for Christmas , and an especial message to you girls , ''
`` Hurry and get done ! Do n't stop to quirk your little finger and simper over your plate , Amy , ''
`` Do n't I wish I could go as a drummer , a vivan -- what 's its name ? Or a nurse , so I could be near him and help him , ''
`` I 'll try and be what he loves to call me , ' a little woman ' and not be rough and wild , but do my duty here instead of wanting to be somewhere else , ''

`` Do you remember how you used to play Pilgrims Progress when you were little things ? Nothing delighted you more than to have me tie my piece bags on your backs for burdens , give you hats and sticks and rolls of paper , and let you travel through the house from the cellar , which was the City of Destruction , up , up , to the housetop , where you had all the lovely things you could collect to make a Celestial City . ''
`` What fun it was , especially going by the lions , fighting Apollyon , and passing through the valley where the hob-goblins were , ''
`` We were in the Slough of Despond tonight , and Mother came and pulled us out as Help did in the book . We ought to have our roll of directions , like Christian . What shall we do about that ? ''
`` She took it out a minute ago , and went off with it to put a ribbon on it , or some such notion , ''
`` Bless the child ! She 's gone and put ` Mother ' on them instead of 'M . March ' . How funny ! ''
`` There 's Mother . Hide the basket , quick ! ''

`` Do n't laugh at me , Jo ! I did n't mean anyone should know till the time came . I only meant to change the little bottle for a big one , and I gave all my money to get it , and I 'm truly trying not to be selfish any more . ''

`` Merry Christmas , little daughters ! I 'm glad you began at once , and hope you will keep on . But I want to say one word before we sit down . Not far away from here lies a poor woman with a little newborn baby . Six children are huddled into one bed to keep from freezing , for they have no fire . There is nothing to eat over there , and the oldest boy came to tell me they were suffering hunger and cold . My girls , will you give them your breakfast as a Christmas present ? ''
`` I 'm so glad you came before we began ! ''
`` Funny angels in hoods and mittens , ''
`` She 's coming ! Strike up , Beth ! Open the door , Amy ! Three cheers for Marmee ! ''
`` Aunt March had a good fit and sent the supper , ''

`` That boy put it into his head , I know he did ! He 's a capital fellow , and I wish we could get acquainted . He looks as if he 'd like to know us but he 's bashful , and Meg is so prim she wo n't let me speak to him when we pass , ''

`` Our cat ran away once , and he brought her back , and we talked over the fence , and were getting on capitally , all about cricket , and so on , when he saw Meg coming , and walked off . I mean to know him some day , for he needs fun , I 'm sure he does , ''
`` It 's a mercy you did n't , Mother ! ''
`` What 's the use of asking that , when you know we shall wear our poplins , because we have n't got anything else ? ''
`` Mine are spoiled with lemonade , and I ca n't get any new ones , so I shall have to go without , ''
`` Then I 'll go without . I do n't care what people say ! ''
`` It 's the dampness drying , ''
`` There , now I 'll take off the papers and you 'll see a cloud of little ringlets , ''
`` Just my luck ! You should n't have asked me to do it . I always spoil everything . I 'm so sorry , but the tongs were too hot , and so I 've made a mess , ''
`` Yes , yes , spandy nice , and Meg has cologne on hers , ''
`` I do believe Marmee would ask that if we were all running away from an earthquake . ''
`` I know I shall forget . If you see me doing anything wrong , just remind me by a wink , will you ? ''
`` Dear me , I did n't know anyone was here ! ''
`` I think I 've had the pleasure of seeing you before . You live near us , do n't you ? ''
`` We did have such a good time over your nice Christmas present . ''
`` I ca n't thrash Aunt March , so I suppose I shall have to bear it . ''
`` Abroad ! ''
`` Do n't I wish I 'd been there ! ''
`` Yes , she makes me think of the German girls , she looks so fresh and quiet , and dances like a lady . ''
`` Curly black hair , brown skin , big black eyes , handsome nose , fine teeth , small hands and feet , taller than I am , very polite , for a boy , and altogether jolly . Wonder how old he is ? ''
`` I suppose you are going to college soon ? I see you pegging away at your books , no , I mean studying hard . ''
`` Are n't you but fifteen ? ''
`` To live in Italy , and to enjoy myself in my own way . ''
`` That 's a splendid polka ! Why do n't you go and try it ? ''
`` I ca n't , for I told Meg I would n't , because ... ''
`` I 've sprained my ankle . That stupid high heel turned and gave me a sad wrench . It aches so , I can hardly stand , and I do n't know how I 'm ever going to get home , ''
`` I knew you 'd hurt your feet with those silly shoes . I 'm sorry . But I do n't see what you can do , except get a carriage , or stay here all night , ''
`` I 'll ask Laurie . He will go , ''
`` Oh , dear , what a blunderbuss I am ! ''
`` I was trying to get something for Meg , who is very tired , and someone shook me , and here I am in a nice state , ''
`` Oh , thank you ! I 'll show you where she is . I do n't offer to take it myself , for I should only get into another scrape if I did . ''
`` Hush ! Do n't say anything , ''
`` It 's nothing . I turned my foot a little , that 's all , ''
`` It 's so early ! You ca n't mean to go yet ? ''
`` I had a capital time . Did you ? ''
`` No , but it was very rude . What were you about all that time , hidden away there ? ''
`` I wish it was Christmas or New Year 's all the time . Would n't it be fun ? ''

`` Well , we ca n't have it , so do n't let us grumble but shoulder our bundles and trudge along as cheerfully as Marmee does . I 'm sure Aunt March is a regular Old Man of the Sea to me , but I suppose when I 've learned to carry her without complaining , she will tumble off , or get so light that I sha n't mind her . ''
`` There never was such a cross family ! ''
`` Cuddle your cats and get over your headache , Bethy . Goodbye , Marmee . We are a set of rascals this morning , but we 'll come home regular angels . Now then , Meg ! ''
`` If Marmee shook her fist instead of kissing her hand to us , it would serve us right , for more ungrateful wretches than we are were never seen , ''
`` I like good strong words that mean something , ''

`` Lucky for you I am , for if I put on crushed airs and tried to be dismal , as you do , we should be in a nice state . Thank goodness , I can always find something funny to keep me up . Do n't croak any more , but come home jolly , there 's a dear . ''
`` Josy-phine ! ''
`` I had a queer time with Aunt today , and , as I got the best of it , I 'll tell you about it , ''

`` Oh , bless you , no ! But she let old Belsham rest , and when I ran back after my gloves this afternoon , there she was , so hard at the Vicar that she did n't hear me laugh as I danced a jig in the hall because of the good time coming . What a pleasant life she might have if only she chose ! I do n't envy her much , in spite of her money , for after all rich people have about as many worries as poor ones , I think , ''
`` Did n't the girls laugh at the picture ? ''
`` Tell another story , Mother , one with a moral to it , like this . I like to think about them afterward , if they are real and not too preachy , ''

`` These girls were anxious to be good and made many excellent resolutions , but they did not keep them very well , and were constantly saying , ` If only we had this , ' or ` If we could only do that , ' quite forgetting how much they already had , and how many things they actually could do . So they asked an old woman what spell they could use to make them happy , and she said , ` When you feel discontented , think over your blessings , and be grateful . ' ''
`` We needed that lesson , and we wo n't forget it . If we do so , you just say to us , as old Chloe did in _ Uncle Tom _ , ` Tink ob yer marcies , chillen ! ' ` Tink ob yer marcies ! ' ''
`` Going out for exercise , ''

`` His grandpa does not know what 's good for him , and keeps him shut up all alone . He needs a party of jolly boys to play with , or somebody young and lively . I 've a great mind to go over and tell the old gentleman so ! ''
`` There he is , ''
`` Poor boy ! All alone and sick this dismal day . It 's a shame ! I 'll toss up a snowball and make him look out , and then say a kind word to him . ''
`` How do you do ? Are you sick ? ''
`` You know us , ''
`` I 'm not quiet and nice , but I 'll come , if Mother will let me . I 'll go ask her . Shut the window , like a good boy , and wait till I come . ''
`` No , I came to amuse you . Shall I read aloud ? ''

`` We 'll never draw that curtain any more , and I give you leave to look as much as you like . I just wish , though , instead of peeping , you 'd come over and see us . Mother is so splendid , she 'd do you heaps of good , and Beth would sing to you if I begged her to , and Amy would dance . Meg and I would make you laugh over our funny stage properties , and we 'd have jolly times . Would n't your grandpa let you ? ''
`` Do n't go to school , I 'm a businessman -- girl , I mean . I go to wait on my great-aunt , and a dear , cross old soul she is , too , ''
`` I 'm not afraid of anything , ''
`` What richness ! ''
`` Theodore Laurence , you ought to be the happiest boy in the world , ''
`` Mercy me ! It 's your grandpa ! ''
`` I think I am a little bit afraid of him , but I do n't know why I should be . Marmee said I might come , and I do n't think you 're any the worse for it , ''
`` Do n't mind me . I 'm happy as a cricket here , ''

`` I 'm sure now that I should n't be afraid of him , for he 's got kind eyes , though his mouth is grim , and he looks as if he had a tremendous will of his own . He is n't as handsome as my grandfather , but I like him . ''
`` Thank you , ma'am , ''
`` Thank you , sir , ''
`` Only trying to be neighborly , sir . ''

`` Yes , sir , he seems a little lonely , and young folks would do him good perhaps . We are only girls , but we should be glad to help if we could , for we do n't forget the splendid Christmas present you sent us , ''
`` Doing nicely , sir . ''
`` What would Meg say to this ? ''
`` Please give these to your mother , and tell her I like the medicine she sent me very much . ''
`` Do you play ? ''
`` Mother , why did n't Mr. Laurence like to have Laurie play ? ''
`` How silly ! ''
`` What do you know about his eyes and his manners ? You never spoke to him , hardly , ''
`` Did he ? ''
`` We have got to get by the lions first , ''

`` Yes , all for you , my precious ! Is n't it splendid of him ? Do n't you think he 's the dearest old man in the world ? Here 's the key in the letter . We did n't open it , but we are dying to know what he says , ''
`` Dear Madam -- ''
`` How nice it sounds ! I wish someone would write to me so ! ''

`` There , Beth , that 's an honor to be proud of , I 'm sure ! Laurie told me how fond Mr. Laurence used to be of the child who died , and how he kept all her little things carefully . Just think , he 's given you her piano . That comes of having big blue eyes and loving music , ''
`` You 'll have to go and thank him , ''
`` How dare you say so , when he 's got both his eyes ? And very handsome ones they are , too , ''
`` Oh , my goodness ! That little goose means a centaur , and she called him a Cyclops , ''
`` I just wish I had a little of the money Laurie spends on that horse , ''
`` Any more than it 's proper to wear all your bonnets and gowns and ribbons at once , that folks may know you 've got them , ''
`` Never mind . Little girls should n't ask questions , ''
`` Now , Meg , be quiet or you will spoil it all . You ca n't go , Amy , so do n't be a baby and whine about it . ''

`` If she goes I sha n't , and if I do n't , Laurie wo n't like it , and it will be very rude , after he invited only us , to go and drag in Amy . I should think she 'd hate to poke herself where she is n't wanted , ''

`` You ca n't sit with us , for our seats are reserved , and you must n't sit alone , so Laurie will give you his place , and that will spoil our pleasure . Or he 'll get another seat for you , and that is n't proper when you were n't asked . You sha n't stir a step , so you may just stay where you are , ''
`` Fiddlesticks ! ''
`` Has anyone taken my book ? ''
`` That 's a fib ! ''
`` You know something about it , and you 'd better tell at once , or I 'll make you . ''
`` What ! My little book I was so fond of , and worked over , and meant to finish before Father got home ? Have you really burned it ? ''
`` I never shall forgive you , ''
`` My dear , do n't let the sun go down upon your anger . Forgive each other , help each other , and begin again tomorrow . ''
`` Everybody is so hateful , I 'll ask Laurie to go skating . He is always kind and jolly , and will put me to rights , I know , ''
`` No matter whether she heard or not , let her take care of herself . ''
`` Are you sure she is safe ? ''
`` Laurie did it all . I only let her go . Mother , if she should die , it would be my fault . ''
`` It 's my dreadful temper ! I try to cure it , I think I have , and then it breaks out worse than ever . Oh , Mother , what shall I do ? What shall I do ? ''
`` Watch and pray , dear , never get tired of trying , and never think it is impossible to conquer your fault , ''
`` Yours , Mother ? Why , you are never angry ! ''

`` I 've been trying to cure it for forty years , and have only succeeded in controlling it . I am angry nearly every day of my life , Jo , but I have learned not to show it , and I still hope to learn not to feel it , though it may take me another forty years to do so . ''
`` Mother , are you angry when you fold your lips tight together and go out of the room sometimes , when Aunt March scolds or people worry you ? ''

`` Yes , I 've learned to check the hasty words that rise to my lips , and when I feel that they mean to break out against my will , I just go away for a minute , and give myself a little shake for being so weak and wicked , ''
`` My good mother used to help me ... ''
`` As you do us ... ''
`` Oh , Mother , if I 'm ever half as good as you , I shall be satisfied , ''

`` I will try , Mother , I truly will . But you must help me , remind me , and keep me from flying out . I used to see Father sometimes put his finger on his lips , and look at you with a very kind but sober face , and you always folded your lips tight and went away . Was he reminding you then ? ''
`` Yes . I asked him to help me so , and he never forgot it , but saved me from many a sharp word by that little gesture and kind look . ''
`` Was it wrong to watch you and to speak of it ? I did n't mean to be rude , but it 's so comfortable to say all I think to you , and feel so safe and happy here . ''
`` Yet you told him to go , Mother , and did n't cry when he went , and never complain now , or seem as if you needed any help , ''

`` I gave my best to the country I love , and kept my tears till he was gone . Why should I complain , when we both have merely done our duty and will surely be the happier for it in the end ? If I do n't seem to need help , it is because I have a better friend , even than Father , to comfort and sustain me . My child , the troubles and temptations of your life are beginning and may be many , but you can overcome and outlive them all if you learn to feel the strength and tenderness of your Heavenly Father as you do that of your earthly one . The more you love and trust Him , the nearer you will feel to Him , and the less you will depend on human power and wisdom . His love and care never tire or change , can never be taken from you , but may become the source of lifelong peace , happiness , and strength . Believe this heartily , and go to God with all your little cares , and hopes , and sins , and sorrows , as freely and confidingly as you come to your mother . ''
`` I let the sun go down on my anger . I would n't forgive her , and today , if it had n't been for Laurie , it might have been too late ! How could I be so wicked ? ''
`` And so nice of Annie Moffat not to forget her promise . A whole fortnight of fun will be regularly splendid , ''
`` It will look nice over my new muslin skirt , and the sash will set it off beautifully . I wish I had n't smashed my coral bracelet , for you might have had it , ''
`` Change it , ''
`` No , I would n't , for the smart caps wo n't match the plain gowns without any trimming on them . Poor folks should n't rig , ''
`` Shall I go away ? ''
`` Is that all ? ''
`` Well , if that is n't the greatest rubbish I ever heard , ''

`` Just wait till I see Annie Moffat , and I 'll show you how to settle such ridiculous stuff . The idea of having ` plans ' and being kind to Laurie because he 's rich and may marry us by-and-by ! Wo n't he shout when I tell him what those silly things say about us poor children ? ''

`` Yes , my dear , I have a great many , all mothers do , but mine differ somewhat from Mrs. Moffat 's , I suspect . I will tell you some of them , for the time has come when a word may set this romantic little head and heart of yours right , on a very serious subject . You are young , Meg , but not too young to understand me , and mothers ' lips are the fittest to speak of such things to girls like you . Jo , your turn will come in time , perhaps , so listen to my ` plans ' and help me carry them out , if they are good . ''
`` Then we 'll be old maids , ''
`` Good ! Bless you ! Now , as there 's nothing like ` taking time by the fetlock ' , as Winkle characteristically observes , allow me to present the new member . ''
`` Good ! Good ! ''
`` Hear ! Hear ! ''
`` Aunt March went today , for which , oh , be joyful ! ''
`` She means vampire , not seaweed , but it does n't matter . It 's too warm to be particular about one 's parts of speech , ''
`` that dozy way would n't suit me . I 've laid in a heap of books , and I 'm going to improve my shining hours reading on my perch in the old apple tree , when I 'm not having l -- ''
`` I now propose a toast , as my ` friend and pardner , Sairy Gamp ' , says . Fun forever , and no grubbing ! ''
`` Mercy on us ! What has happened ? ''
`` That 's easy enough , and I like the idea , I 'm aching for something to do , that is , some new amusement , you know , ''
`` Poor little souls , they will have a hard time , I 'm afraid , but they wo n't suffer , and it will do them good , ''
`` Never mind , I 'll get the dinner and be servant , you be mistress , keep your hands nice , see company , and give orders , ''
`` I do n't want you to do anything but be civil to him and help to the pudding . You 'll give me your advice if I get in a muddle , wo n't you ? ''
`` Of course I shall . I 'm not a fool . ''
`` Get what you like , and do n't disturb me . I 'm going out to dinner and ca n't worry about things at home , ''
`` Everything is out of sorts , somehow , ''
`` There 's Beth crying , that 's a sure sign that something is wrong in this family . If Amy is bothering , I 'll shake her . ''

`` The funeral shall be this afternoon , and we will all go . Now , do n't cry , Bethy . It 's a pity , but nothing goes right this week , and Pip has had the worst of the experiment . Make the shroud , and lay him in my box , and after the dinner party , we 'll have a nice little funeral , ''
`` Here 's a sweet prospect ! ''
`` Well , they can eat beef and bread and butter , if they are hungry , only it 's mortifying to have to spend your whole morning for nothing , ''
`` Oh , what is it ? ''
`` I have n't strength of mind enough to clear up now , so we will sober ourselves with a funeral , ''
`` What a dreadful day this has been ! ''
`` I do n't ! ''
`` Lounging and larking does n't pay , ''
`` Suppose you learn plain cooking . That 's a useful accomplishment , which no woman should be without , ''
`` We 'll work like bees , and love it too , see if we do n't , ''
`` Here 's richness ! ''
`` That 's my good girl . You do try to fight off your shyness , and I love you for it . Fighting faults is n't easy , as I know , and a cheery word kind of gives a lift . Thank you , Mother , ''
`` Now let 's fly round , and do double duty today , so that we can play tomorrow with free minds , ''
`` I just will , though , for it 's capital , so shady , light , and big . It will make fun , and I do n't mind being a guy if I 'm comfortable . ''
`` You pushed it . I saw you . It 's my turn now , ''
`` We do n't cheat in America , but you can , if you choose , ''
`` Yankees have a trick of being generous to their enemies , ''

`` Do n't praise me , Meg , for I could box his ears this minute . I should certainly have boiled over if I had n't stayed among the nettles till I got my rage under control enough to hold my tongue . It 's simmering now , so I hope he 'll keep out of my way , ''
`` Thank you , I prefer spiders , ''
`` How dare you remind me of that horrid dinner party , when yours is so nice in every way ? ''
`` Snuffbox , ''

`` and , as they danced , the rubbishy old castle turned to a man-of-war in full sail . ` Up with the jib , reef the tops ' l halliards , helm hard alee , and man the guns ! ' roared the captain , as a Portuguese pirate hove in sight , with a flag black as ink flying from her foremast . ` Go in and win , my hearties ! ' says the captain , and a tremendous fight began . Of course the British beat -- they always do . ''
`` No , they do n't ! ''
`` Let 's try it , ''
`` Who are your heroes ? ''
`` What silly questions you ask ! ''
`` It 's a very good one for you , ''
`` A pair of boot lacings , ''
`` Genius . Do n't you wish you could give it to me , Laurie ? ''
`` Did n't you cheat at croquet ? ''
`` What do you like best ? ''
`` Well , I think Truth is a very silly play . Let 's have a sensible game of Authors to refresh our minds , ''
`` What do you like to talk about ? ''
`` Bless her heart ! She pities him , so she is good to him , ''
`` Of course you may . We should have asked you before , only we thought you would n't care for such a girl 's game as this . ''
`` Finish this story while I set my heel , ''
`` Who cares ? ''
`` Who told you ? ''

`` Mother likes to have us out-of-doors as much as possible , so we bring our work here and have nice times . For the fun of it we bring our things in these bags , wear the old hats , use poles to climb the hill , and play pilgrims , as we used to do years ago . We call this hill the Delectable Mountain , for we can look far away and see the country where we hope to live some time . ''
`` You 'll get there , Beth , sooner or later , no fear of that , ''
`` Would n't it be fun if all the castles in the air which we make could come true , and we could live in them ? ''
`` Why do n't you say you 'd have a splendid , wise , good husband and some angelic little children ? You know your castle would n't be perfect without , ''
`` I 've got the key to my castle in the air , but whether I can unlock the door remains to be seen , ''
`` If we are all alive ten years hence , let 's meet , and see how many of us have got our wishes , or how much nearer we are then than now , ''
`` You and I will be twenty-six , Teddy , Beth twenty-four , and Amy twenty-two . What a venerable party ! ''
`` I advise you to sail away in one of your ships , and never come home again till you have tried your own way , ''
`` Then you may come , and I 'll teach you to knit as the Scotchmen do . There 's a demand for socks just now , ''
`` There , I 've done my best ! If this wo n't suit I shall have to wait till I can do better . ''
`` You 're the oddest fellow I ever saw . How many did you have out ? ''

`` Oh , dear , I 'm so sorry , for you 'll get to liking it better and better , and will waste time and money , and grow like those dreadful boys . I did hope you 'd stay respectable and be a satisfaction to your friends , ''
`` I have n't got any , ''
`` Well , I 've left two stories with a newspaperman , and he 's to give his answer next week , ''

`` It wo n't fail . Why , Jo , your stories are works of Shakespeare compared to half the rubbish that is published every day . Wo n't it be fun to see them in print , and sha n't we feel proud of our authoress ? ''
`` Where 's your secret ? Play fair , Teddy , or I 'll never believe you again , ''
`` Is that all ? ''
`` I 'd like to see anyone try it , ''
`` I do n't think secrets agree with me , I feel rumpled up in my mind since you told me that , ''

`` I wish I was a horse , then I could run for miles in this splendid air , and not lose my breath . It was capital , but see what a guy it 's made me . Go , pick up my things , like a cherub , as you are , ''
`` Getting leaves , ''
`` I 'm glad of it ! ''
`` Because if you care much about riches , you will never go and marry a poor man , ''
`` Nothing but a story , wo n't amount to much , I guess , ''
`` Stop jabbering , girls , and I 'll tell you everything , ''

`` And when I went to get my answer , the man said he liked them both , but did n't pay beginners , only let them print in his paper , and noticed the stories . It was good practice , he said , and when the beginners improved , anyone would pay . So I let him have the two stories , and today this was sent to me , and Laurie caught me with it and insisted on seeing it , so I let him . And he said it was good , and I shall write more , and he 's going to get the next paid for , and I am so happy , for in time I may be able to support myself and help the girls . ''
`` That 's the reason I was born in it , ''
`` My patience , how blue we are ! ''
`` Leave a note at Aunt March 's . Jo , give me that pen and paper . ''
`` No , it 's mine honestly . I did n't beg , borrow , or steal it . I earned it , and I do n't think you 'll blame me , for I only sold what was my own . ''

`` It does n't affect the fate of the nation , so do n't wail , Beth . It will be good for my vanity , I was getting too proud of my wig . It will do my brains good to have that mop taken off . My head feels deliciously light and cool , and the barber said I could soon have a curly crop , which will be boyish , becoming , and easy to keep in order . I 'm satisfied , so please take the money and let 's have supper . ''
`` No , I wo n't ! ''
`` Well , I was wild to do something for Father , ''
`` You need n't feel wicked , my child ! You had no winter things and got the simplest with your own hard earnings , ''
`` Jo , dear , what is it ? Are you crying about father ? ''
`` My ... My hair ! ''
`` I 'm not sorry , ''
`` Brown , that is , sometimes . Blue are lovely . ''

`` Children , I leave you to Hannah 's care and Mr. Laurence 's protection . Hannah is faithfulness itself , and our good neighbor will guard you as if you were his own . I have no fears for you , yet I am anxious that you should take this trouble rightly . Do n't grieve and fret when I am gone , or think that you can be idle and comfort yourselves by being idle and trying to forget . Go on with your work as usual , for work is a blessed solace . Hope and keep busy , and whatever happens , remember that you never can be fatherless . ''
`` I feel as if there had been an earthquake , ''
`` That 's so like my Beth ! ''
`` Goodbye , Meggy , I hope the Kings wo n't strain today . Do n't fret about Father , dear , ''
`` It 's well enough for me to go out with Laurie , but not well enough to go to the Hummels ' , ''
`` Ask Hannah for some nice little mess , and take it round , Beth , the air will do you good , ''
`` I 'd go but I want to finish my writing . ''
`` Christopher Columbus ! What 's the matter ? ''
`` My poor dear , how dreadful for you ! I ought to have gone , ''
`` No , you wo n't ! ''
`` If Mother was only at home ! ''
`` I guess not . Do n't care if I do . Serve me right , selfish pig , to let you go , and stay writing rubbish myself ! ''
`` I shall , because it 's my fault she is sick . I told Mother I 'd do the errands , and I have n't , ''
`` What a trying world it is ! ''
`` Do you study in vacation time ? ''
`` I have great hopes for my boy , ''
`` What do you want now ? ''
`` Father is much better , ''
`` I 've sent for Mother , ''

`` Yes , it is . She does n't know us , she does n't even talk about the flocks of green doves , as she calls the vine leaves on the wall . She does n't look like my Beth , and there 's nobody to help us bear it . Mother and father both gone , and God seems so far away I ca n't find Him . ''
`` I 'm so glad Father is better . Now she wo n't feel so bad about leaving him . Oh , me ! It does seem as if all the troubles came in a heap , and I got the heaviest part on my shoulders , ''
`` Oh , yes , she tries to , but she ca n't love Bethy as I do , and she wo n't miss her as I shall . Beth is my conscience , and I ca n't give her up . I ca n't ! I ca n't ! ''
`` The good and dear people always do die , ''
`` I drink -- Health to my Beth ! You are a good doctor , Teddy , and such a comfortable friend . How can I ever pay you ? ''
`` What is it ? ''
`` No , thank you . I 'll do it by proxy , when your grandpa comes . Do n't tease , but go home and rest , for you 'll be up half the night . Bless you , Teddy , bless you ! ''
`` happy , oh , so happy ! ''
`` If god spares Beth , I 'll try to love and serve Him all my life , ''
`` Beth is dead , and Meg is afraid to tell me . ''
`` Good-by , my Beth . Good-by ! ''
`` If Mother would only come now ! ''
`` Hark ! ''
`` No . I should have shut the door in his face if he had , ''
`` Mercy me ! I do n't know anything about love and such nonsense ! ''

`` Oh , dear ! I know you 'll take his part . He 's been good to Father , and you wo n't send him away , but let Meg marry him , if she wants to . Mean thing ! To go petting Papa and helping you , just to wheedle you into liking him . ''

`` She 'll see those handsome eyes that she talks about , and then it will be all up with her . She 's got such a soft heart , it will melt like butter in the sun if anyone looks sentimentlly at her . She read the short reports he sent more than she did your letters , and pinched me when I spoke of it , and likes brown eyes , and does n't think John an ugly name , and she 'll go and fall in love , and there 's an end of peace and fun , and cozy times together . I see it all ! They 'll go lovering around the house , and we shall have to dodge . Meg will be absorbed and no good to me any more . Brooke will scratch up a fortune somehow , carry her off , and make a hole in the family , and I shall break my heart , and everything will be abominably uncomfortable . Oh , dear me ! Why were n't we all boys , then there would n't be any bother . ''
`` Had n't you rather have her marry a rich man ? ''
`` I understand , Mother , and quite agree , but I 'm disappointed about Meg , for I 'd planned to have her marry Teddy by-and-by and sit in the lap of luxury all her days . Would n't it be nice ? ''
`` He is younger than she , you know , ''

`` Only a little , he 's old for his age , and tall , and can be quite grown-up in his manners if he likes . Then he 's rich and generous and good , and loves us all , and I say it 's a pity my plan is spoiled . ''
`` Only one of my stupid speeches . I 'm going to bed . Come , Peggy , ''

`` She feels it in the air -- love , I mean -- and she 's going very fast . She 's got most of the symptoms -- is twittery and cross , does n't eat , lies awake , and mopes in corners . I caught her singing that song he gave her , and once she said ` John ' , as you do , and then turned as red as a poppy . Whatever shall we do ? ''
`` Here 's a note to you , Meg , all sealed up . How odd ! Teddy never seals mine , ''
`` Me ! I 've done nothing ! What 's she talking about ? ''
`` Oh , the little villain ! That 's the way he meant to pay me for keeping my word to Mother . I 'll give him a hearty scolding and bring him over to beg pardon , ''
`` Stop , Jo , you must clear yourself first . You have played so many pranks that I am afraid you have had a hand in this . ''
`` On my word , Mother , I have n't ! I never saw that note before , and do n't know anything about it , as true as I live ! ''
`` If I had taken part in it I 'd have done it better than this , and have written a sensible note . I should think you 'd have known Mr. Brooke would n't write such stuff as that , ''
`` Here 's a scrape ! Do let me bring that wicked boy over to explain and be lectured . I ca n't rest till I get hold of him . ''

`` I only said I was too young to do anything about it yet , that I did n't wish to have secrets from you , and he must speak to father . I was very grateful for his kindness , and would be his friend , but nothing more , for a long while . ''
`` You are almost equal to Caroline Percy , who was a pattern of prudence ! Tell on , Meg . What did he say to that ? ''
`` I do n't believe Brooke ever saw either of these letters . Teddy wrote both , and keeps yours to crow over me with because I would n't tell him my secret . ''
`` That will do , Jo . I 'll comfort Meg while you go and get Laurie . I shall sift the matter to the bottom , and put a stop to such pranks at once . ''
`` Is Mr. Laurence in ? ''
`` I 'll go and see what the matter is . I 'm not afraid of either of them . ''
`` Who did it ? ''
`` That 's nothing . I often shake you , and you do n't mind , ''
`` What pepper pots you are ! ''
`` What fun you 'd have ! I wish I could run off too , ''

`` Come on , then ! Why not ? You go and surprise your father , and I 'll stir up old Brooke . It would be a glorious joke . Let 's do it , Jo . We 'll leave a letter saying we are all right , and trot off at once . I 've got money enough . It will do you good , and no harm , as you go to your father . ''
`` Hold your tongue ! ''
`` Bad boy , be quiet ! Sit down and think of your own sins , do n't go making me add to mine . If I get your grandpa to apologize for the shaking , will you give up running away ? ''
`` If I can manage the young one , I can the old one , ''
`` It 's only me , Sir , come to return a book , ''
`` Yes , please . I like old Sam so well , I think I 'll try the second volume , ''
`` He did wrong , but we forgave him , and all promised not to say a word to anyone , ''

`` Hang the _ Rambler ! _ Come down and give me your word that this harum-scarum boy of mine has n't done anything ungrateful or impertinent . If he has , after all your kindness to him , I 'll thrash him with my own hands . ''
`` So am I , but a kind word will govern me when all the king 's horses and all the king 's men could n't , ''
`` Oh , dear no , Sir . You are rather too kind sometimes , and then just a trifle hasty when he tries your patience . Do n't you think you are ? ''
`` I 'll tell you , he 'll run away . ''

`` He wo n't do it unless he is very much worried , and only threatens it sometimes , when he gets tired of studying . I often think I should like to , especially since my hair was cut , so if you ever miss us , you may advertise for two boys and look among the ships bound for India . ''
`` He wo n't come , Sir . He feels badly because you did n't believe him when he said he could n't tell . I think the shaking hurt his feelings very much . ''
`` Go and eat your dinner , you 'll feel better after it . Men always croak when they are hungry , ''
`` So am I , ''
`` I hate estimable young men with brown eyes ! ''
`` Just a year ago we were groaning over the dismal Christmas we expected to have . Do you remember ? ''
`` How do you know ? Did Mother tell you ? ''

`` I see a young lady who pins her collar straight , laces her boots neatly , and neither whistles , talks slang , nor lies on the rug as she used to do . Her face is rather thin and pale just now , with watching and anxiety , but I like to look at it , for it has grown gentler , and her voice is lower . She does n't bounce , but moves quietly , and takes care of a certain little person in a motherly way which delights me . I rather miss my wild girl , but if I get a strong , helpful , tenderhearted woman in her place , I shall feel quite satisfied . I do n't know whether the shearing sobered our black sheep , but I do know that in all Washington I could n't find anything beautiful enough to be bought with the five-and-twenty dollars my good girl sent me . ''
`` What are you thinking of , Beth ? ''
`` He 's showing you how your John will go on by-and-by . Touching , is n't it ? ''

`` We ca n't , for something has been said , and Laurie 's mischief has spoiled you for me . I see it , and so does Mother . You are not like your old self a bit , and seem ever so far away from me . I do n't mean to plague you and will bear it like a man , but I do wish it was all settled . I hate to wait , so if you mean ever to do it , make haste and have it over quickly , ''

`` I 'm not so silly and weak as you think . I know just what I should say , for I 've planned it all , so I need n't be taken unawares . There 's no knowing what may happen , and I wished to be prepared . ''
`` Would you mind telling me what you 'd say ? ''
`` Do n't mean to have any . It 's fun to watch other people philander , but I should feel like a fool doing it myself , ''
`` I thought you were going to tell your speech to that man , ''
`` Yes , John , ''
`` She has seen him away as we planned , and that affair is settled . I 'll go and hear the fun , and have a good laugh over it . ''
`` Oh , do somebody go down quick ! John Brooke is acting dreadfully , and Meg likes it ! ''
`` Hope the next will end better , ''
`` Here comes Laurie . Now we shall have some sensible conversation . ''
`` I do n't approve of the match , but I 've made up my mind to bear it , and shall not say a word against it , ''
`` It can never be the same again . I 've lost my dearest friend , ''
`` I know you will , and I 'm ever so much obliged . You are always a great comfort to me , Teddy , ''
`` I rather think it would , but there 's no knowing what may happen in three years , ''
`` I think not , for I might see something sad , and everyone looks so happy now , I do n't believe they could be much improved . ''
`` If Meg had four , the house would n't hold them , and master and missis would have to camp in the garden , ''
`` Which side won the last match , Teddy ? ''
`` Now , Teddy , I want to talk seriously to you about tomorrow , ''
`` Very . Why , have you got into a scrape and want to know how he 'll take it ? ''

`` You are so generous and kind-hearted that you let people borrow , and ca n't say ` No ' to anyone . We heard about Henshaw and all you did for him . If you always spent money in that way , no one would blame you , ''
`` I 'll leave you in peace if you 'll only let your hair grow . I 'm not aristocratic , but I do object to being seen with a person who looks like a young prize fighter , ''
`` Of course he had . We do n't want any more marrying in this family for years to come . Mercy on us , what are the children thinking of ? ''

`` I do n't like that sort of thing . I 'm too busy to be worried with nonsense , and I think it 's dreadful to break up families so . Now do n't say any more about it . Meg 's wedding has turned all our heads , and we talk of nothing but lovers and such absurdities . I do n't wish to get cross , so let 's change the subject ; ''
`` And I drink ` long life to your resolution ' , Teddy , ''

`` Why in the world should you spend your money , worry your family , and turn the house upside down for a parcel of girls who do n't care a sixpence for you ? I thought you had too much pride and sense to truckle to any mortal woman just because she wears French boots and rides in a coupe , ''
`` Shall I rush into town and demand one ? ''
`` Run , Beth , and help Hannah clear half the things off the table . It will be too absurd to put a luncheon for twelve before a single girl , ''
`` It 's a pity Laurie is n't here to help us , ''

`` I thought I should have died when I saw you two girls rattling about in the what-you-call-it , like two little kernels in a very big nutshell , and Mother waiting in state to receive the throng , ''
`` I think you and I could do as well as that if we tried , ''
`` Do you know her ? ''
`` Do you say she makes a good living out of stories like this ? ''
`` Guess she does ! She knows just what folks like , and gets paid well for writing it . ''
`` Send Beth and Mother to the seaside for a month or two , ''

`` Now I must either bundle it back in to my tin kitchen to mold , pay for printing it myself , or chop it up to suit purchasers and get what I can for it . Fame is a very good thing to have in the house , but cash is more convenient , so I wish to take the sense of the meeting on this important subject , ''

`` that 's just it . I 've been fussing over the thing so long , I really do n't know whether it 's good , bad , or indifferent . It will be a great help to have cool , impartial persons take a look at it , and tell me what they think of it . ''
`` But Mr. Allen says , ` Leave out the explanations , make it brief and dramatic , and let the characters tell the story ' , ''
`` Well , ''

`` if my people are ` philosophical and metaphysical ' , it is n't my fault , for I know nothing about such things , except what I hear father say , sometimes . If I 've got some of his wise ideas jumbled up with my romance , so much the better for me . Now , Beth , what do you say ? ''
`` You said , Mother , that criticism would help me . But how can it , when it 's so contradictory that I do n't know whether I 've written a promising book or broken all the ten commandments ? ''
`` Not being a genius , like Keats , it wo n't kill me , ''

`` and I 've got the joke on my side , after all , for the parts that were taken straight out of real life are denounced as impossible and absurd , and the scenes that I made up out of my own silly head are pronounced ` charmingly natural , tender , and true ' . So I 'll comfort myself with that , and when I 'm ready , I 'll up again and take another . ''
`` Shut your eyes and hold out your arms , ''
`` Then you sha n't see your nevvy , ''
`` It 's the best joke of the season , is n't it ? I would n't have told you , for I set my heart on surprising you , and I flatter myself I 've done it , ''
`` Amy put a blue ribbon on the boy and a pink on the girl , French fashion , so you can always tell . Besides , one has blue eyes and one brown . Kiss them , Uncle Teddy , ''
`` Of course they will , they are used to it now . Do it this minute , sir ! ''
`` Daisy and Demi , just the thing ! I knew Teddy would do it , ''

`` Now , that 's shirking . It 's a lovely day , no prospect of rain , and you pride yourself on keeping promises , so be honorable , come and do your duty , and then be at peace for another six months . ''

`` You 're an artful little puss to flatter and wheedle your cross old sister in that way . The idea of my being aristocratic and well-bred , and your being afraid to go anywhere alone ! I do n't know which is the most absurd . Well , I 'll go if I must , and do my best . You shall be commander of the expedition , and I 'll obey blindly , will that satisfy you ? ''
`` You 're highly satisfactory . Turn slowly round , and let me get a careful view . ''
`` You are a thing of beauty and a joy forever , ''

`` Hold it up when you walk , but drop it in the house . The sweeping style suits you best , and you must learn to trail your skirts gracefully . You have n't half buttoned one cuff , do it at once . You 'll never look finished if you are not careful about the little details , for they make up the pleasing whole . ''
`` Oh , Amy painted it . You ca n't buy those soft shades , so we paint ours any color we like . It 's a great comfort to have an artistic sister . ''

`` That 's nothing compared to some of her brilliant performances . There 's nothing the child ca n't do . Why , she wanted a pair of blue boots for Sallie 's party , so she just painted her soiled white ones the loveliest shade of sky blue you ever saw , and they looked exactly like satin , ''

`` Amy , we must go . Good-by , dear , do come and see us . We are pining for a visit . I do n't dare to ask you , Mr. Lamb , but if you should come , I do n't think I shall have the heart to send you away . ''
`` Did n't I do well ? ''
`` How shall I behave here ? ''
`` Then I 'll enjoy myself . The boys are at home , and we 'll have a comfortable time . Goodness knows I need a little change , for elegance has a bad effect upon my constitution , ''
`` It was such fun to hear about Laurie 's larks . ''
`` Capital boys , are n't they ? I feel quite young and brisk again after that . ''
`` No , it would n't , ''

`` I neither like , respect , nor admire Tudor , though his grandfather 's uncle 's nephew 's niece was a third cousin to a lord . Tommy is poor and bashful and good and very clever . I think well of him , and like to show that I do , for he is a gentleman in spite of the brown paper parcels . ''
`` Not the least , my dear , ''
`` so let us look amiable , and drop a card here , as the Kings are evidently out , for which I 'm deeply grateful . ''
`` What a good girl you are , Amy ! ''
`` I 'm not , ''
`` Thank you , I will . Come Amy . ''

`` I merely intend to make myself entrancingly agreeable to every one I know , and to keep them in your corner as long as possible . Teddy and his boys will lend a hand , and we 'll have a good time yet . ''
`` Oh , Teddy , such doings ! ''

`` The flowers are not at all nice , Amy says , and the fresh ones may not arrive in time . I do n't wish to be unjust or suspicious , but I should n't wonder if they never came at all . When people do one mean thing they are very likely to do another , ''
`` Go away , Teddy , I 'm busy . ''
`` Tucked away out of sight , I dare say , ''
`` She has sold everything she had that was worth selling , and now she is enjoying herself . The flower table is always attractive , you know , ` especially to gentlemen ' . ''
`` Is Amy 's illumination anywhere about ? I took a fancy to buy that for Father , ''
`` You 've a deal more principle and generosity and nobleness of character than I ever gave you credit for , Amy . You 've behaved sweetly , and I respect you with all my heart , ''

`` I understand now what you mean , and I 'll never laugh at you again . You are getting on faster than you think , and I 'll take lessons of you in true politeness , for you 've learned the secret , I believe . Try away , deary , you 'll get your reward some day , and no one will be more delighted than I shall . ''
`` Aunt Carrol is going abroad next month , and wants ... ''
`` Me to go with her ! ''
`` It 's always so . Amy has all the fun and I have all the work . It is n't fair , oh , it is n't fair ! ''
`` Oh , my tongue , my abominable tongue ! Why ca n't I learn to keep it quiet ? ''
`` I wish you could have gone , but there is no hope of it this time , so try to bear it cheerfully , and do n't sadden Amy 's pleasure by reproaches or regrets . ''
`` I 'll try , ''
`` I 'll take a leaf out of her book , and try not only to seem glad , but to be so , and not grudge her one minute of happiness . But it wo n't be easy , for it is a dreadful disappointment , ''
`` Suppose you have n't ? ''
`` No , you wo n't . You hate hard work , and you 'll marry some rich man , and come home to sit in the lap of luxury all your days , ''
`` Thank you . I 'll remind you of your promise when that joyful day comes , if it ever does , ''
`` I have tried once or twice , but she either evaded my questions or looked so distressed that I stopped . I never force my children 's confidence , and I seldom have to wait for long . ''

`` I think she is growing up , and so begins to dream dreams , and have hopes and fears and fidgets , without knowing why or being able to explain them . Why , Mother , Beth 's eighteen , but we do n't realize it , and treat her like a child , forgetting she 's a woman . ''
`` I 'll settle Bethy 's troubles , and then I 'll tell you mine . They are not very wearing , so they 'll keep . ''
`` I never dreamed of such a thing . What will Mother say ? I wonder if her ... ''
`` If he should n't love back again , how dreadful it would be . He must . I 'll make him ! ''

`` Oh dear , we are growing up with a vengeance . Here 's Meg married and a mamma , Amy flourishing away at Paris , and Beth in love . I 'm the only one that has sense enough to keep out of mischief . ''

`` No thank you , sir , you 're very charming , but you 've no more stability than a weathercock . So you need n't write touching notes and smile in that insinuating way , for it wo n't do a bit of good , and I wo n't have it . ''
`` I told you so . ''
`` Who knows ? Stranger things have happened , ''
`` No slang , ''
`` No , she 's not to be bothered with me , but you like that sort of thing , unless you 've suddenly lost your taste for it . Have you ? Do you hate your boy , and want to fire pillows at him ? ''
`` I 'm glad of it , that 's one of your foolish extravagances , sending flowers and things to girls for whom you do n't care two pins , ''
`` Well , it does look pleasant , but I ca n't learn how it 's done . I 've tried , because one feels awkward in company not to do as everybody else is doing , but I do n't seem to get on ''
`` If you must have a ` vent ' , Teddy , go and devote yourself to one of the ` pretty , modest girls ' whom you do respect , and not waste your time with the silly ones . ''

`` Yes , I do , but you 'd better wait till you are through college , on the whole , and be fitting yourself for the place meantime . You 're not half good enough for -- well , whoever the modest girl may be . ''
`` Mercy on us , this will never do , ''
`` Go and sing to me . I 'm dying for some music , and always like yours . ''
`` Well , you ca n't , there is n't room . Go and make yourself useful , since you are too big to be ornamental . I thought you hated to be tied to a woman 's apron string ? ''
`` Are you going ? ''
`` No , no , do n't call her , do n't tell her . I shall be better soon . Lie down here and ` poor ' my head . I 'll be quiet and go to sleep , indeed I will . ''
`` You asked me the other day what my wishes were . I 'll tell you one of them , Marmee , ''

`` I want something new . I feel restless and anxious to be seeing , doing , and learning more than I am . I brood too much over my own small affairs , and need stirring up , so as I can be spared this winter , I 'd like to hop a little way and try my wings . ''
`` May I know the others ? ''
`` Then you do n't care for him in the way it is evident he begins to care for you ? ''
`` You are sure of his feeling for you ? ''
`` I agree with you , and if it can be managed you shall go . ''
`` How Mrs. Moffat would wonder at your want of management , if she knew , and how she will rejoice that Annie may still hope . ''
`` Yes , she owned she had a trouble , and promised to tell me by-and-by . I said no more , for I think I know it , ''

`` Let us say nothing about it to him till the plan is settled , then I 'll run away before he can collect his wits and be tragic . Beth must think I 'm going to please myself , as I am , for I ca n't talk about Laurie to her . But she can pet and comfort him after I 'm gone , and so cure him of this romantic notion . He 's been through so many little trials of the sort , he 's used to it , and will soon get over his lovelornity . ''
`` Excuse me , I was looking for the Weekly Volcano office . I wished to see Mr. Dashwood . ''
`` A friend of mine desired me to offer -- a story -- just as an experiment -- would like your opinion -- be glad to write more if this suits . ''
`` Well , you can leave it , if you like . We 've more of this sort of thing on hand than we know what to do with at present , but I 'll run my eye over it , and give you an answer next week . ''
`` What do you -- that is , what compensation -- ''
`` Very well , you can have it , ''
`` Shall I tell my friend you will take another if she has one better than this ? ''
`` None at all , if you please , she does n't wish her name to appear and has no nom de plume , ''
`` I 'll call . Good morning , Sir . ''
`` That 's it ! ''
`` It 's evident he does n't look in his glass before coming down , ''
`` Mees Marsch , for what do you laugh in your master 's face ? Haf you no respect for me , that you go on so bad ? ''
`` How can I be respectful , Sir , when you forget to take your hat off ? ''

`` All may not be bad , only silly , you know , and if there is a demand for it , I do n't see any harm in supplying it . Many very respectable people make an honest living out of what are called sensation stories , ''
`` Mine are not like that , they are only silly , never bad , so I wo n't be worried , ''
`` Shall we go on , Sir ? I 'll be very good and proper now . ''
`` I shall hope so , ''

`` They are trash , and will soon be worse trash if I go on , for each is more sensational than the last . I 've gone blindly on , hurting myself and other people , for the sake of money . I know it 's so , for I ca n't read this stuff in sober earnest without being horribly ashamed of it , and what should I do if they were seen at home or Mr. Bhaer got hold of them ? ''
`` Yes , that 's the best place for such inflammable nonsense . I 'd better burn the house down , I suppose , than let other people blow themselves up with my gunpowder , ''
`` I think I have n't done much harm yet , and may keep this to pay for my time , ''

`` I almost wish I had n't any conscience , it 's so inconvenient . If I did n't care about doing right , and did n't feel uncomfortable when doing wrong , I should get on capitally . I ca n't help wishing sometimes , that Mother and Father had n't been so particular about such things . ''
`` I do n't know anything . I 'll wait until I do before I try again , and meantime , ` sweep mud in the street ' if I ca n't do better , that 's honest , at least . ''
`` Now , Sir , you wo n't forget to come and see us , if you ever travel our way , will you ? I 'll never forgive you if you do , for I want them all to know my friend . ''
`` Yes , my boy Teddy . I 'm very proud of him and should like you to see him . ''
`` Oh , deary me ! I know he 'll say something , and then what shall I do ? ''
`` I forgot it . ''
`` Now you must have a good long holiday ! ''
`` I intend to . ''
`` No , Teddy . Please do n't ! ''
`` Say what you like then . I 'll listen , ''
`` I wanted to save you this . I thought you 'd understand ... ''
`` Really , truly , dear . ''

`` Oh , Teddy , I 'm sorry , so desperately sorry , I could kill myself if it would do any good ! I wish you would n't take it so hard , I ca n't help it . You know it 's impossible for people to make themselves love other people if they do n't , ''
`` Laurie , I want to tell you something . ''
`` Tell what ? ''
`` What old man ? ''

`` Do n't swear , Teddy ! He is n't old , nor anything bad , but good and kind , and the best friend I 've got , next to you . Pray , do n't fly into a passion . I want to be kind , but I know I shall get angry if you abuse my Professor . I have n't the least idea of loving him or anybody else . ''
`` What shall I do with him ? ''
`` You have n't heard what I wanted to tell you . Sit down and listen , for indeed I want to do right and make you happy , ''
`` I agree with Mother that you and I are not suited to each other , because our quick tempers and strong wills would probably make us very miserable , if we were so foolish as to ... ''
`` Now do be reasonable , and take a sensible view of the case , ''
`` I wish I had n't . ''
`` I ca n't say ` yes ' truly , so I wo n't say it at all . You 'll see that I 'm right , by-and-by , and thank me for it ... ''
`` Yes , you will ! ''
`` Yes , I will live and die for him , if he ever comes and makes me love him in spite of myself , and you must do the best you can ! ''
`` Oh , where are you going ? ''
`` That will do him good , and he 'll come home in such a tender , penitent state of mind , that I sha n't dare to see him , ''
`` Is this what made you so unhappy in the autumn , Beth ? You did not feel it then , and keep it to yourself so long , did you ? ''
`` Oh , Beth , and you did n't tell me , did n't let me comfort and help you ? How could you shut me out , bear it all alone ? ''
`` And I thought you loved him , Beth , and I went away because I could n't , ''
`` Then you did n't , dearie ? I was afraid it was so , and imagined your poor little heart full of lovelornity all that while . ''
`` Not through me , ''

`` It shall be stopped , your tide must not turn so soon , nineteen is too young , Beth . I ca n't let you go . I 'll work and pray and fight against it . I 'll keep you in spite of everything . There must be ways , it ca n't be too late . God wo n't be so cruel as to take you from me , ''
`` I 'm glad to go , ''
`` I try to be willing , ''
`` I think they will see it without words , ''
`` If I can . But , Beth , I do n't give up yet . I 'm going to believe that it is a sick fancy , and not let you think it 's true . ''
`` She is coming in the spring , and I mean that you shall be all ready to see and enjoy her . I 'm going to have you well and rosy by that time , ''

`` Jo , dear , do n't hope any more . It wo n't do any good . I 'm sure of that . We wo n't be miserable , but enjoy being together while we wait . We 'll have happy times , for I do n't suffer much , and I think the tide will go out easily , if you help me . ''
`` Not asleep , but so happy , dear . See , I found this and read it . I knew you would n't care . Have I been all that to you , Jo ? ''
`` I 'll try , Beth . ''
`` I ca n't do it . I was n't meant for a life like this , and I know I shall break away and do something desperate if somebody does n't come and help me , ''
`` Father , talk to me as you did to Beth . I need it more than she did , for I 'm all wrong . ''
`` Marriage is an excellent thing , after all . I wonder if I should blossom out half as well as you have , if I tried it ? , always _ ` perwisin ' _ I could , ''
`` Frost opens chestnut burrs , ma'am , and it takes a good shake to bring them down . Boys go nutting , and I do n't care to be bagged by them , ''
`` Do n't believe I can . ''
`` I do n't understand it . What can there be in a simple little story like that to make people praise it so ? ''
`` If there is anything good or true in what I write , it is n't mine . I owe it all to you and Mother and Beth , ''
`` You like it , Mother ? ''
`` And that 's our cool , reserved , and worldly Amy ! Truly , love does work miracles . How very , very happy they must be ! ''

`` Oh , if he only would ! So kind , so good , so patient with me always , my dear old Fritz . I did n't value him half enough when I had him , but now how I should love to see him , for everyone seems going away from me , and I 'm all alone . ''

`` An old maid , that 's what I 'm to be . A literary spinster , with a pen for a spouse , a family of stories for children , and twenty years hence a morsel of fame , perhaps , when , like poor Johnson , I 'm old and ca n't enjoy it , solitary , and ca n't share it , independent , and do n't need it . Well , I need n't be a sour saint nor a selfish sinner , and , I dare say , old maids are very comfortable when they get used to it , but ... ''
`` Your what ? ''
`` Mercy on us . What dreadful thing will you do next ? ''
`` Not a word , unless you let me come in my old place , and promise not to barricade . ''
`` The old pillow is up garret , and we do n't need it now . So , come and ` fess , Teddy . ''
`` That 's like her . Well , you look it , ''
`` How can I , when the mere idea of you , married and settled , is so irresistibly funny that I ca n't keep sober ! ''
`` Fib number one . Amy did it to please you . Go on , and tell the truth , if you can , sir . ''
`` How did you ever get Aunt to agree ? ''
`` Are n't we proud of those two words , and do n't we like to say them ? ''
`` When , where , how ? ''
`` Six weeks ago , at the American consul 's , in Paris , a very quiet wedding of course , for even in our happiness we did n't forget dear little Beth . ''
`` Why did n't you let us know afterward ? ''

`` I ca n't make it true that you children are really married and going to set up housekeeping . Why , it seems only yesterday that I was buttoning Amy 's pinafore , and pulling your hair when you teased . Mercy me , how time does fly ! ''

`` No , I had Father and Mother to help me , and the dear babies to comfort me , and the thought that you and Amy were safe and happy , to make the troubles here easier to bear . I am lonely , sometimes , but I dare say it 's good for me , and ... ''

`` If I should n't be in the way , it would be very pleasant . I begin to feel quite young already , for somehow all my troubles seemed to fly away when you came . You always were a comfort , Teddy , ''
`` That ever I should live to see you a henpecked husband and enjoying it ! ''
`` How well they look together ! I was right , and Laurie has found the beautiful , accomplished girl who will become his home better than clumsy old Jo , and be a pride , not a torment to him . ''
`` You must be my girl now , ''
`` I 'll try to fill her place , sir . ''
`` Should n't wonder if she drove six white horses , ate off gold plate , and wore diamonds and point lace every day . Teddy thinks nothing too good for her , ''
`` I do n't care , ''
`` Oh , Mr. Bhaer , I am so glad to see you ! ''
`` Dear old fellow ! He could n't have got himself up with more care if he 'd been going a-wooing , ''
`` We must have our sing , in the good old way , for we are all together again once more , ''
`` Now , we must finish with Mignon 's song , for Mr. Bhaer sings that , ''
`` You will sing with me ? We go excellently well together . ''
`` I thought you 'd like him , ''
`` Weathercock can without the wind , ''
`` What are you going to do with yourselves after you get settled ? ''
`` I know it will . Happy Amy ! ''
`` Father , Father , here 's the Professor ! ''
`` He 's a born Weller , ''
`` You precocious chick ! Who put that into your head ? ''
`` I always do take a walk toward evening , and I do n't know why I should give it up , just because I happen to meet the Professor on his way out , ''
`` as Friedrich -- I mean Mr. Bhaer -- does n't like tea . ''
`` Disgusted , I dare say , and gone home as suddenly as he came . It 's nothing to me , of course , but I should think he would have come and bid us goodbye like a gentleman , ''
`` Yes , Marmee , do you want anything in town ? I 've got to run in and get some paper , ''
`` I believe so , ''
`` If you happen to meet Mr. Bhaer , bring him home to tea . I quite long to see the dear man , ''
`` Yes , thank you . ''
`` We thought you had gone , ''
`` I 'm always glad to see you , sir . ''
`` Successfully , I hope ? ''
`` Tell me , please ! I like to know all about the -- the boys , ''
`` Indeed you should . How splendid it will be to have you doing what you like , and be able to see you often , and the boys ! ''
`` So far away ! ''
`` So far away ! ''
`` What will we buy ? ''
`` Hamburg grapes . Yes , we shall drink to the Fatherland in those ? ''
`` Yes , sir ? ''
`` Yes , sir , ''
`` Yes , sir , ''
`` I 'm going very fast , and he 's getting dearer every minute , ''
`` Does this suit you , Mr. Bhaer ? ''
`` Yes , it 's late , and I 'm _ so _ tired . ''
`` I beg your pardon . I did n't see the name distinctly . Never mind , I can walk . I 'm used to plodding in the mud , ''
`` Oh , yes ! ''
`` Oh , yes ! ''
`` Is n't ` thou ' a little sentimental ? ''
`` Well , then , why did n't thou tell me all this sooner ? ''
`` Yes , the first love is the best , but be so contented , for I never had another . Teddy was only a boy , and soon got over his little fancy , ''
`` I like that , ''
`` How could that bring you ? ''
`` It 's very bad poetry , but I felt it when I wrote it , one day when I was very lonely , and had a good cry on a rag bag . I never thought it would go where it could tell tales , ''
`` And so you came to find that it was not too poor , but the one precious thing I needed , ''
`` What made you stay away so long ? ''
`` I 'm glad you are poor . I could n't bear a rich husband , ''

`` Do n't fear poverty . I 've known it long enough to lose my dread and be happy working for those I love , and do n't call yourself old -- forty is the prime of life . I could n't help loving you if you were seventy ! ''

`` I may be strong-minded , but no one can say I 'm out of my sphere now , for woman 's special mission is supposed to be drying tears and bearing burdens . I 'm to carry my share , Friedrich , and help to earn the home . Make up your mind to that , or I 'll never go , ''
`` Not empty now , ''
`` Welcome home ! ''
`` No , I do n't , ''
`` The crop we are going to raise is a profitable one , ''
`` I knew you 'd stand by me , sir . Amy does too -- I see it in her eyes , though she prudently waits to turn it over in her mind before she speaks . Now , my dear people , ''

`` just understand that this is n't a new idea of mine , but a long cherished plan . Before my Fritz came , I used to think how , when I 'd made my fortune , and no one needed me at home , I 'd hire a big house , and pick up some poor , forlorn little lads who had n't any mothers , and take care of them , and make life jolly for them before it was too late . I see so many going to ruin for want of help at the right minute , I love so to do anything for them , I seem to feel their wants , and sympathize with their troubles , and oh , I should so like to be a mother to them ! ''

`` I told my plan to Fritz once , and he said it was just what he would like , and agreed to try it when we got rich . Bless his dear heart , he 's been doing it all his life -- helping poor boys , I mean , not getting rich , that he 'll never be . Money does n't stay in his pocket long enough to lay up any . But now , thanks to my good old aunt , who loved me better than I ever deserved , I 'm rich , at least I feel so , and we can live at Plumfield perfectly well , if we have a flourishing school . It 's just the place for boys , the house is big , and the furniture strong and plain . There 's plenty of room for dozens inside , and splendid grounds outside . They could help in the garden and orchard . Such work is healthy , is n't it , sir ? Then Fritz could train and teach in his own way , and Father will help him . I can feed and nurse and pet and scold them , and Mother will be my stand-by . I 've always longed for lots of boys , and never had enough , now I can fill the house full and revel in the little dears to my heart 's content . Think what luxury -- Plumfield my own , and a wilderness of boys to enjoy it with me . ''
`` I do n't see anything funny , ''
`` I do think that families are the most beautiful things in all the world ! ''
`` Dear fellows ! It does my heart good to see them forget business and frolic for a day , ''

`` Yes , I remember , but the life I wanted then seems selfish , lonely , and cold to me now . I have n't given up the hope that I may write a good book yet , but I can wait , and I 'm sure it will be all the better for such experiences and illustrations as these , ''
`` There 's no need for me to say it , for everyone can see that I 'm far happier than I deserve , ''
`` Not half so good as yours , Mother . Here it is , and we never can thank you enough for the patient sowing and reaping you have done , ''
`` Quite right , and beautifully written . Please add that I send my love to John , ''
`` Please choose to learn , Meg . I love to teach , and this is easier than German , ''
`` You have only to wait , I am to do the work , ''
`` Do n't feel that I am separated from you , Marmee dear , or that I love you any the less for loving John so much , ''
`` I 'm afraid something has happened . Step into the garden , Scott , while I look up Mrs. Brooke , ''
`` My dearest girl , what is the matter ? ''
`` What worries you dear ? Has anything dreadful happened ? ''
`` The ... The jelly wo n't jell and I do n't know what to do ! ''

`` Is that all ? Fling it out of the window , and do n't bother any more about it . I 'll buy you quarts if you want it , but for heaven 's sake do n't have hysterics , for I 've brought Jack Scott home to dinner , and ... ''
`` A man to dinner , and everything in a mess ! John Brooke , how could you do such a thing ? ''
`` Hush , he 's in the garden ! I forgot the confounded jelly , but it ca n't be helped now , ''

`` I did n't know it this morning , and there was no time to send word , for I met him on the way out . I never thought of asking leave , when you have always told me to do as I liked . I never tried it before , and hang me if I ever do again ! ''
`` Well , I like that ! Where 's the beef and vegetables I sent home , and the pudding you promised ? ''
`` who might be cruel , but nobody should know it , ''
`` I will be the first to say , ` Forgive me ' ''
`` This is the beginning . I 'll do my part , and have nothing to reproach myself with , ''
`` It was too bad to laugh at the poor little jelly pots . Forgive me , dear . I never will again ! ''
`` Well , dear , what is the ` dem 'd total ' , as Mr. Mantalini says ? ''
`` Twenty-five yards of silk seems a good deal to cover one small woman , but I 've no doubt my wife will look as fine as Ned Moffat 's when she gets it on , ''
`` I was afraid of this . I do my best , Meg . ''

`` I 'm getting old and ugly . John does n't find me interesting any longer , so he leaves his faded wife and goes to see his pretty neighbor , who has no incumbrances . Well , the babies love me , they do n't care if I am thin and pale and have n't time to crimp my hair , they are my comfort , and some day John will see what I 've gladly sacrificed for them , wo n't he , my precious ? ''
`` I would n't tell anyone except you , Mother , but I really do need advice , for if John goes on much longer I might as well be widowed , ''
`` I do it out of respect for you , my dear , ''
`` Well , it 's altogether delightful , and like old times . This tastes right . I drink your health , dear . ''
`` Now this wo n't do , ''
`` He 's my child , and I wo n't have his temper spoiled by indulgence . Go down , my dear , and leave the boy to me . ''
`` Poor little man , he 's worn out with sleep and crying . I 'll cover him up , and then go and set Meg 's heart at rest , ''
`` Well , I really do n't see what we are coming to . ''
`` It 's a love of a bonnet , but I prefer the face inside , for it looks young and happy again , ''

`` Well , I had a talk with Marmee the other day , and told her how nervous and cross and out of sorts I felt , and she said I needed change and less care , so Hannah is to help me with the children , and I 'm to see to things about the house more , and now and then have a little fun , just to keep me from getting to be a fidgety , broken-down old woman before my time . It 's only an experiment , John , and I want to try it for your sake as much as for mine , because I 've neglected you shamefully lately , and I 'm going to make home what it used to be , if I can . You do n't object , I hope ? ''
`` When I have one of my own , I hope it will be as happy as the three I know and love the best . If John and my Fritz were only here , it would be quite a little heaven on earth , ''
`` It is not for me , I must not hope it now , ''
