`` I do n't think it 's fair for some girls to have plenty of pretty things , and other girls nothing at all , ''
`` I shall get a nice box of Faber 's drawing pencils ; I really need them , ''
`` I do n't believe any of you suffer as I do , ''

`` for you do n't have to go to school with impertinent girls , who plague you if you do n't know your lessons , and laugh at your dresses , and label your father if he is n't rich , and insult you when your nose is n't nice . ''
`` I know what I mean , and you need n't be statirical about it . It 's proper to use good words , and improve your vocabilary , ''
`` Jo does use such slang words ! ''
`` No , I shall ! ''
`` I 'll get a little bottle of cologne . She likes it , and it wo n't cost much , so I 'll have some left to buy my pencils , ''

`` I ca n't help it . I never saw anyone faint , and I do n't choose to make myself all black and blue , tumbling flat as you do . If I can go down easily , I 'll drop . If I ca n't , I shall fall into a chair and be graceful . I do n't care if Hugo does come at me with a pistol , ''

`` Well , dearies , how have you got on today ? There was so much to do , getting the boxes ready to go tomorrow , that I did n't come home to dinner . Has anyone called , Beth ? How is your cold , Meg ? Jo , you look tired to death . Come and kiss me , baby . ''
`` It must be very disagreeable to sleep in a tent , and eat all sorts of bad-tasting things , and drink out of a tin mug , ''

`` I do n't remember much about it , except that I was afraid of the cellar and the dark entry , and always liked the cake and milk we had up at the top . If I was n't too old for such things , I 'd rather like to play it over again , ''
`` Really , Mother ? Where are our bundles ? ''
`` I 'm glad mine is blue , ''
`` Why , where is Amy 's bottle of cologne ? ''
`` I shall take the cream and the muffings , ''
`` Is it fairies ? ''
`` What a queer smell ! It 's like burned feathers , ''
`` It is n't spoiled . Just frizzle it , and tie your ribbon so the ends come on your forehead a bit , and it will look like the last fashion . I 've seen many girls do it so , ''
`` You 're the crossest person in it ! ''
`` My nose . ''
`` When Papa was rich we did so-and-so , ''
`` My only comfort , ''
`` I think being disgraced in school is a great deal try_inger _ than anything bad boys can do , ''

`` Laugh ? Not one ! They sat still as mice , and Susie cried quarts , I know she did . I did n't envy her then , for I felt that millions of carnelian rings would n't have made me happy after that . I never , never should have got over such a agonizing mortification . ''
`` I do n't complain near as much as the others do , and I shall be more careful than ever now , for I 've had warning from Susie 's downfall , ''
`` I do n't call myself a child , and I 'm not in my teens yet , ''
`` Oh , Beth , he 's sent you ... ''
`` That boy is a perfect cyclops , is n't he ? ''
`` You need n't be so rude , it 's only a ` lapse of lingy ' , as Mr. Davis says , ''

`` Oh , thank you ! It must be so nice to have pocket money ! I 'll have a grand feast , for I have n't tasted a lime this week . I felt delicate about taking any , as I could n't return them , and I 'm actually suffering for one . ''
`` Miss March , come to the desk . ''
`` Bring with you the limes you have in your desk , ''
`` Not quite , ''
`` Bring the rest immediately . ''
`` Your hand , Miss March ! ''
`` That 's good ! I wish all the girls would leave , and spoil his old school . It 's perfectly maddening to think of those lovely limes , ''
`` Do you mean you are glad I was disgraced before the whole school ? ''
`` Is Laurie an accomplished boy ? ''
`` And he is n't conceited , is he ? ''
`` I see . It 's nice to have accomplishments and be elegant , but not to show off or get perked up , ''
`` Girls , where are you going ? ''
`` run away , dear ''
`` Yes , we are . Now do be still , and stop bothering . ''

`` I do n't like that half as well as going with you and Laurie . Please let me . I 've been sick with this cold so long , and shut up , I 'm dying for some fun . Do , Meg ! I 'll be ever so good , ''
`` I shall go . Meg says I may , and if I pay for myself , Laurie has n't anything to do with it . ''
`` You 'll be sorry for this , Jo March , see if you ai n't . ''
`` Scold as much as you like , you 'll never see your silly old book again , ''
`` Yes , I did ! I told you I 'd make you pay for being so cross yesterday , and I have , so ... ''
`` You wicked , wicked girl ! I never can write it again , and I 'll never forgive you as long as I live . ''
`` Please forgive me , Jo . I 'm very , very sorry . ''
`` It was an abominable thing , and she does n't deserve to be forgiven . ''
`` I 'll try , ''
`` I 'll go on to the first bend , and see if it 's all right before we begin to race , ''
`` I wish I was going to have a fine time and wear all these nice things , ''
`` What did Mother give you out of the treasure box ? ''
`` Never mind , you 've got the tarlaton for the big party , and you always look like an angel in white , ''
`` Aunt March is a regular samphire , is she not ? ''
`` What shall you do all your vacation ? ''
`` Do n't say ` larks ! ' ''
`` Do n't let us do any lessons , Beth , for a while , but play all the time and rest , as the girls mean to , ''
`` Put him in the oven , and maybe he will get warm and revive , ''
`` Not a bit like home , ''
`` I shall learn to make buttonholes , and attend to my parts of speech . ''
`` I had a box of chocolate drops , and the picture I wanted to copy , ''
`` Little goose girl , who kept a hundred fat geese in the field , ''
`` I dote upon it . My sister , Meg , used to ride when Papa was rich , but we do n't keep any horses now , except Ellen Tree , ''
`` Dear , how charming ! I hope I shall go abroad some day , but I 'd rather go to Rome than the Row , ''
`` My sister Beth is a very fastidious girl , when she likes to be , ''
`` He 'll laugh , ''
`` It 's often so , and we like to watch it , for it is never the same , but always splendid , ''
`` I have ever so many wishes , but the pet one is to be an artist , and go to Rome , and do fine pictures , and be the best artist in the whole world , ''
`` Here 's mine ! ''
`` It 's very trying , but we never can make her _ commy la fo _ , ''
`` You 'd better read it aloud . That will amuse us and keep you out of mischief , ''
`` I like that about the splendid picture , ''
`` It 's very good , ''
`` Jo and I are going to make fortunes for you all . Just wait ten years , and see if we do n't , ''
`` We three will be ready in a minute , ''
`` What made you do it ? ''
`` Who was Jimmy ? ''
`` No need of that . Beth and I can keep house perfectly well , ''
`` I think anxiety is very interesting , ''

`` Now be a sensible little woman , and do as they say . No , do n't cry , but hear what a jolly plan I 've got . You go to Aunt March 's , and I 'll come and take you out every day , driving or walking , and we 'll have capital times . Wo n't that be better than moping here ? ''
`` I do n't wish to be sent off as if I was in the way , ''
`` But it 's dull at Aunt March 's , and she is so cross , ''
`` Well -- I guess I will , ''

`` No more than I expected , if you are allowed to go poking about among poor folks . Amy can stay and make herself useful if she is n't sick , which I 've no doubt she will be , looks like it now . Do n't cry , child , it worries me to hear people sniff . ''
`` I do n't think I can bear it , but I 'll try , ''

And when the lamps are lighted , it 's like looking at a picture to see the fire , and you all around the table with your mother . Her face is right opposite , and it looks so sweet behind the flowers , I ca n't help watching it . I have n't got any mother , you know . ''
`` I think he would , if your mother asked him . He 's very kind , though he does not look so , and he lets me do what I like , pretty much , only he 's afraid I might be a bother to strangers , ''

`` That 's bad . You ought to make an effort and go visiting everywhere you are asked , then you 'll have plenty of friends , and pleasant places to go to . Never mind being bashful . It wo n't last long if you keep going . ''
`` Oh ! That does me no end of good . Tell on , please , ''
`` If you like them so much , come down and see ours . Grandfather is out , so you need n't be afraid , ''
`` A fellow ca n't live on books , ''
`` I 'm a great deal better for it , and ever so much obliged . I 'm only afraid you are very tired of talking to me . It was so pleasant , I could n't bear to stop , ''
`` Would you mind if I left you for a minute ? I suppose I must see him , ''
`` I did n't know you 'd come , sir , ''
`` Sometimes , ''
`` Do n't know how . Too stupid to learn , but I love music dearly . ''
`` Are you the musical girl ? ''
`` So it is ! ''
`` You do know her , and she helps you better than anyone else could , ''
`` Keep near the shore . It is n't safe in the middle . ''
`` Bring a rail . Quick , quick ! ''
`` Now then , we must walk her home as fast as we can . Pile our things on her , while I get off these confounded skates , ''
`` Jo wanted me to come , and tell her how you looked , so I did , ''
`` I shall say I did n't know you , for you look so grown-up and unlike yourself , I 'm quite afraid of you , ''
`` Yes , I think she would , ''
`` Why not ? ''
`` Please forgive my rudeness , and come and dance with me . ''
`` Not a bit of it , I 'm dying to do it . Come , I 'll be good . I do n't like your gown , but I do think you are just splendid . ''
`` Pin it round your neck , and then it will be useful , ''
`` Wo n't I ! ''
`` Then why did you do it ? ''
`` I 'll say the first with all my heart , but how about the other ? You do n't look as if you were having a good time . Are you ? ''
`` Here comes Ned Moffat . What does he want ? ''
`` Wish tomorrow was here , then , ''
`` Silence a la mort , ''
`` My faithful friend and noble patron , ''
`` who has so flatteringly presented me , is not to be blamed for the base stratagem of tonight . I planned it , and she only gave in after lots of teasing . ''
`` There 's salt here , ''

`` I had an uncommonly good time that day , and have n't got over it yet . This is no credit to me , you know , I do n't do anything . It 's you and Meg and Brooke who make it all go , and I 'm no end obliged to you . What shall we do when we ca n't eat anymore ? ''
`` I guess the princess gave him a posy , and opened the gate after a while , ''
`` What do you most wish for ? ''
`` Let 's give it to him , ''
`` Good ! Did n't you take your story out of _ The Sea Lion ? _ ''
`` He 's a true John Bull . Now , Miss Sallie , you shall have a chance without waiting to draw . I 'll harrrow up your feelings first by asking if you do n't think you are something of a flirt , ''
`` What in the world are those girls about now ? ''
`` Well , that 's cool , ''
`` to have a picnic and never ask me ! They ca n't be going in the boat , for they have n't got the key . Perhaps they forgot it . I 'll take it to them , and see what 's going on . ''
`` Here 's a landscape ! ''

`` Much obliged . I 'll do anything if you 'll let me stop a bit , for it 's as dull as the Desert of Sahara down there . Shall I sew , read , cone , draw , or do all at once ? Bring on your bears . I 'm ready . ''
`` Yes 'm . ''
`` Yes , I know , ''
`` Go on , please , ''
`` Yes , I should think so , ''
`` How beautiful that is ! ''
`` I 've made such quantities it would be hard to choose which I 'd have , ''
`` Would n't you have a master for your castle in the air ? ''
`` Do n't you wish for anything else ? ''
`` We 're an ambitious set , are n't we ? Every one of us , but Beth , wants to be rich and famous , and gorgeous in every respect . I do wonder if any of us will ever get our wishes , ''
`` I 've got the key to mine , but I 'm not allowed to try it . Hang college ! ''
`` Yes , you have , ''
`` Is she ? By Jupiter , I will , if I only get the chance ! ''

`` I ought to be satisfied to please Grandfather , and I do try , but it 's working against the grain , you see , and comes hard . He wants me to be an India merchant , as he was , and I 'd rather be shot . I hate tea and silk and spices , and every sort of rubbish his old ships bring , and I do n't care how soon they go to the bottom when I own them . Going to college ought to satisfy him , for if I give him four years he ought to let me off from the business . But he 's set , and I 've got to do just as he did , unless I break away and please myself , as my father did . If there was anyone left to stay with the old gentleman , I 'd do it tomorrow . ''
`` What do you know about him ? ''
`` So he is , dear old fellow ! ''
`` I do n't tell tales , ''

`` I 'm the one to be forgiven . I 'm cross and have been out of sorts all day . I like to have you tell me my faults and be sisterly , so do n't mind if I am grumpy sometimes . I thank you all the same . ''
`` May I come again ? ''
`` What are you laughing at ? You are up to some mischief , Jo , ''
`` You can teach me , and then when we play _ Hamlet _ , you can be Laertes , and we 'll make a fine thing of the fencing scene . ''
`` Ca n't a fellow take a little innocent amusement now and then without losing his respectability ? ''
`` Wo n't she ? ''
`` A little , when you look moody and discontented , as you sometimes do , for you 've got such a strong will , if you once get started wrong , I 'm afraid it would be hard to stop you . ''
`` Are you going to deliver lectures all the way home ? ''
`` You know you have -- you ca n't hide anything , so up and ` fess , or I wo n't tell , ''
`` Hurrah for Miss March , the celebrated American authoress ! ''
`` Tell , then . ''
`` How do you know ? ''
`` So should I ! ''
`` Race down this hill with me , and you 'll be all right , ''
`` And hairpins , ''
`` Do you envy her , Meg ? ''
`` Any letter from Father , girls ? ''

`` Wo n't some of you come for a drive ? I 've been working away at mathematics till my head is in a muddle , and I 'm going to freshen my wits by a brisk turn . It 's a dull day , but the air is n't bad , and I 'm going to take Brooke home , so it will be gay inside , if it is n't out . Come , Jo , you and Beth will go , wo n't you ? ''
`` Can I do anything for you , Madam Mother ? ''
`` Now go , dear , but do n't kill yourself driving at a desperate pace . There is no need of that . ''
`` That 's my only comfort . ''
`` Good girl ! Call Meg , and tell her you 'll give in , ''
`` How is the little dear ? ''
`` Well , do n't make a porcupine of yourself , it is n't becoming . Settle your wig , Jo , and tell me if I shall telegraph to your mother , or do anything ? ''
`` Stay where you are , Jo . I 'm errand boy to this establishment , ''
`` I follow the good example my neighbors set me , ''
`` What is it ? Is Beth worse ? ''
`` Good for you , Jo ! Did you do it on your own responsibility ? ''
`` Oh , Jo , it 's not so bad as that ? ''
`` I 'm here . Hold on to me , Jo , dear ! ''
`` Does n't Meg pull fair ? ''
`` I do n't think she will die . She 's so good , and we all love her so much , I do n't believe God will take her away yet . ''
`` Poor girl , you 're worn out . It is n't like you to be forlorn . Stop a bit . I 'll hearten you up in a jiffy . ''
`` I 'll send my bill , by-and-by , and tonight I 'll give you something that will warm the cockles of your heart better than quarts of wine , ''
`` I telegraphed to your mother yesterday , and Brooke answered she 'd come at once , and she 'll be here tonight , and everything will be all right . Are n't you glad I did it ? ''
`` Oh , Laurie ! Oh , Mother ! I am so glad ! ''

`` Oh , do n't ! I did n't mean to , it was dreadful of me , but you were such a dear to go and do it in spite of Hannah that I could n't help flying at you . Tell me all about it , and do n't give me wine again , it makes me act so . ''
`` I do n't mind , ''
`` Fly at me again . I rather liked it , ''
`` Girls , she 's come ! She 's come ! ''
`` Ai n't we fine ? Get along , you fright ! Hold your tongue ! Kiss me , dear ! Ha ! Ha ! ''
`` Did the spider accept the old fellow 's invitation ? ''
`` I 'd wring your neck if you were mine , you old torment , ''
`` Allyluyer ! bless your buttons , dear ! ''
`` I want you to read that , please , and tell me if it is legal and right . I felt I ought to do it , for life is uncertain and I do n't want any ill feeling over my tomb . ''
`` What put it into your head ? Did anyone tell you about Beth 's giving away her things ? ''

`` I 'm sorry I spoke , but as I did , I 'll tell you . She felt so ill one day that she told Jo she wanted to give her piano to Meg , her cats to you , and the poor old doll to Jo , who would love it for her sake . She was sorry she had so little to give , and left locks of hair to the rest of us , and her best love to Grandpa . She never thought of a will . ''
`` Put one in mine then , that I wish all my curls cut off , and given round to my friends . I forgot it , but I want it done though it will spoil my looks . ''
`` Is there really any danger about Beth ? ''
`` I 'm afraid there is , but we must hope for the best , so do n't cry , dear . ''
`` Your devoted John . ''
`` It was altogether abominable , and I do n't deserve to be spoken to for a month , but you will , though , wo n't you ? ''
`` Please forgive me for being so cross . I came to make it up , and ca n't go away till I have . ''
`` I 've been shaken , and I wo n't bear it ! ''
`` That 's the fun of it , ''
`` I know Meg would wet-blanket such a proposal , but I thought you had more spirit , ''
`` Yes , but you wo n't do it , ''
`` That 's a ` label ' on my ` sect ' , ''
`` I knew Brooke would have it all his own way , he always does , for when he makes up his mind to accomplish anything , it 's done though the sky falls , ''
`` I 'll come if I 'm at the ends of the earth , for the sight of Jo 's face alone on that occasion would be worth a long journey . You do n't look festive , ma'am , what 's the matter ? ''
`` You do n't give her up . You only go halves , ''
`` You 've got me , anyhow . I 'm not good for much , I know , but I 'll stand by you , Jo , all the days of my life . Upon my word I will ! ''
`` That 's true . Do n't you wish you could take a look forward and see where we shall all be then ? I do , ''

`` For Mrs. John Brooke , with the maker 's congratulations and compliments . Bless you , Beth ! What a refreshing spectacle you are , Jo . Amy , you are getting altogether too handsome for a single lady . ''
`` More cruel than ever . Do n't you see how I 'm pining away ? ''
`` It 's a useful thing to have in the house in case of fire or thieves , ''
`` Any time when John is away and you get frightened , Mrs. Meg , just swing that out of the front window , and it will rouse the neighborhood in a jiffy . Nice thing , is n't it ? ''
`` Come , Jo , do n't desert a fellow . I 'm in such a state of exhaustion I ca n't get home without help . Do n't take off your apron , whatever you do , it 's peculiarly becoming , ''
`` Such as fellows going to college , hey ? ''
`` Now , Jo , do you think I 'd look your mother in the face and say ` All right ' , if it was n't ? ''
`` Then do n't go and be suspicious . I only want some money , ''

`` Of course not , but I do n't see the use of your having seventeen waistcoats , endless neckties , and a new hat every time you come home . I thought you 'd got over the dandy period , but every now and then it breaks out in a new spot . Just now it 's the fashion to be hideous , to make your head look like a scrubbing brush , wear a strait jacket , orange gloves , and clumping square-toed boots . If it was cheap ugliness , I 'd say nothing , but it costs as much as the other , and I do n't get any satisfaction out of it . ''
`` This unassuming style promotes study , that 's why we adopt it , ''

`` By the way , Jo , I think that little Parker is really getting desperate about Amy . He talks of her constantly , writes poetry , and moons about in a most suspicious manner . He 'd better nip his little passion in the bud , had n't he ? ''
`` It 's a fast age , and I do n't know what we are coming to , ma'am . You are a mere infant , but you 'll go next , Jo , and we 'll be left lamenting , ''
`` You wo n't give anyone a chance , ''
`` Mark my words , Jo , you 'll go next . ''
`` Jupiter Ammon ! Jo 's upset the cake again ! ''
`` Has Jo smashed all the bottles by accident ? ''
`` or am I merely laboring under a delusion that I saw some lying about loose this morning ? ''
`` I like that ! For I 've seen enough harm done to wish other women would think as you do . ''
`` I promise , Mrs. Brooke ! ''
`` All the married people take hands and dance round the new-made husband and wife , as the Germans do , while we bachelors and spinsters prance in couples outside ! ''
`` I 'll do my best to gratify you , Sir , ''
`` I thank you all very much for helping me , and I 'll thank you still more if you wo n't allude to it for a month , at least . ''
`` How 's the little mamma ? Where is everybody ? Why did n't you tell me before I came home ? ''
`` I will , I will ! Only you must be responsible for damages . ''
`` Twins , by Jupiter ! ''
`` Take 'em quick , somebody ! I 'm going to laugh , and I shall drop 'em . ''

`` I never was more staggered in my life . Is n't it fun ? Are they boys ? What are you going to name them ? Let 's have another look . Hold me up , Jo , for upon my life it 's one too many for me , ''
`` Most remarkable children I ever saw . Which is which ? ''
`` I 'm afraid they might n't like it , ''
`` There , I knew they did n't like it ! That 's the boy , see him kick , he hits out with his fists like a good one . Now then , young Brooke , pitch into a man of your own size , will you ? ''
`` Name him Demijohn , and call him Demi for short , ''
`` As sure as this is my girl ! ''
`` A flock of our fellows are going to drive over by-and-by , and I 'll be hanged if I do n't make them buy every flower she 's got , and camp down before her table afterward , ''
`` Now , Jo , how could you think there was any need of asking ? They are just as much yours as mine . Do n't we always go halves in everything ? ''
`` Could n't you do it now ? ''
`` Very well , my son , for a small boy ! ''
`` The reward of merit for a magnanimous March , ''
`` Oh , take care of them for me , and if anything should happen ... ''
`` I will , dear , I will , and if anything happens , I 'll come and comfort you , ''
`` Now , this is filling at the price . ''
`` Much you know about it , ma'am , ''
`` You really advise it ? ''
`` That I 'm not ! ''
`` Ah , that depends on who wears the apron ! ''
`` Up with the bonnets of bonnie Dundee , ''
`` So I am , and I mean this one shall stay turned . ''
`` It wo n't do a bit of good , Jo . My eye is on you , so mind what you do , or I 'll come and bring you home . ''
`` I 've got to stay for this confounded supper , but I shall be home early tomorrow . You 'll come and meet me as usual , girls ? ''
`` Where 's the jew 's - harp , Jo ? ''

`` I 've loved you ever since I 've known you , Jo , could n't help it , you 've been so good to me . I 've tried to show it , but you would n't let me . Now I 'm going to make you hear , and give me an answer , for I ca n't go on so any longer . ''
`` I know you did , but the girls are so queer you never know what they mean . They say no when they mean yes , and drive a man out of his wits just for the fun of it , ''
`` Do n't tell me that , Jo , I ca n't bear it now ! ''
`` Yes , we will if we get the chance , ''
`` Do n't disappoint us , dear ! Everyone expects it . Grandpa has set his heart upon it , your people like it , and I ca n't get on without you . Say you will , and let 's be happy . Do , do ! ''
`` I 'll be hanged if I do ! ''
`` Anything more ? ''
`` I know better ! ''
`` You 'll be sorry some day , Jo . ''
`` Jo , dear , come in . I want you . ''
`` Who told you ? ''
`` Then there 's an end of it ! ''
`` I do n't intend to run away from a girl . Jo ca n't prevent my seeing her , and I shall stay and do it as long as I like , ''
`` Anywhere . I do n't care what becomes of me , ''
`` Ah , but I did n't mean to go alone ! ''
`` Myself . ''
`` I 'm a selfish brute , but -- you know -- Grandfather -- ''

`` Lord help me , yes , I do know , for I 've been through it all before , once in my own young days , and then with your father . Now , my dear boy , just sit quietly down and hear my plan . It 's all settled , and can be carried out at once , ''
`` Well , sir , what is it ? ''
`` But you hate traveling , Sir . I ca n't ask it of you at your age , ''
`` It 's all right , never mind , ''
`` Thank you . Where now ? ''

`` Why , you see , he hates to travel , and I hate to keep still , so we each suit ourselves , and there is no trouble . I am often with him , and he enjoys my adventures , while I like to feel that someone is glad to see me when I get back from my wanderings . Dirty old hole , is n't it ? ''

`` The dirt is picturesque , so I do n't mind . The river and the hills are delicious , and these glimpses of the narrow cross streets are my delight . Now we shall have to wait for that procession to pass . It 's going to the Church of St. John . ''
`` That mademoiselle has made good use of her time , and the result is charming , ''

`` Do you remember the Cathedral and the Corso , the fishermen dragging their nets in the bay , and the lovely road to Villa Franca , Schubert 's Tower , just below , and best of all , that speck far out to sea which they say is Corsica ? ''
`` Good evening , Diana ! ''
`` Here are your flowers . I arranged them myself , remembering that you did n't like what Hannah calls a ` sot-bookay ' , ''
`` Thank you . It is n't what it should be , but you have improved it , ''
`` I 'm glad of it , ''
`` Do you care to dance ? ''
`` One usually does at a ball . ''
`` You look like Balzac 's ' _ Femme Peinte Par Elle-Meme _ ' , ''
`` What do you call this stuff ? ''
`` None of that , it is forbidden . I 'd rather take coffee than compliments just now . No , do n't lounge , it makes me nervous . ''
`` Where did you learn all this sort of thing ? ''
`` Well -- the general air , the style , the self-possession , the -- the -- illusion -- you know ''
`` Well , yes , but is n't it rather warm for such a long walk ? ''
`` Then I 'll go with pleasure . ''
`` No , nor felt such thorns , ''
`` Thank you , I will , ''

`` Not so bad as it seems , for I should only plague him if I went , so I might as well stay and plague you a little longer , you can bear it better , in fact I think it agrees with you excellently , ''
`` I 'm all ready for the secrets . ''
`` She 's very busy . I 'm roving about so , it 's impossible to be regular , you know . When do you begin your great work of art , Raphaella ? ''
`` Now I 'm going to play brother , and ask questions . May I ? ''
`` You are not engaged , I hope ? ''
`` Try , then . I give you leave , ''
`` Saint Laurence on a gridiron , ''
`` Hang Miss Randal ! ''
`` No , you did n't , you knew perfectly well I never cared for anyone but Jo , ''
`` Do n't , that 's her name for me ! ''
`` Wait till you 've tried it yourself , ''
`` Do you think Jo would despise me as you do ? ''
`` I did fail , say what you will , for Jo would n't love me , ''
`` Much obliged . You 've improved immensely since then , and I congratulate you . May I venture to suggest in ' a honeymoon paradise ' that five o'clock is the dinner hour at your hotel ? ''
`` Unfortunately I have an engagement . Au revoir , madamoiselle , ''
`` Go and do something splendid that will make her love you . ''
`` No , I wo n't ! I have n't forgotten , I never can . I 'll try again , and if that fails , why then ... ''
`` So I will , at once . Poor little girl , it will be a sad going home for her , I 'm afraid , ''
`` Fred is a good fellow , but not at all the man I fancied you would ever like , ''
`` Oh , Laurie , Laurie , I knew you 'd come to me ! ''

`` Poor little soul , you look as if you 'd grieved yourself half sick ! I 'm going to take care of you , so do n't cry any more , but come and walk about with me , the wind is too chilly for you to sit still , ''
`` Little children , love one another . ''
`` I 'm not tired , but you may take an oar , if you like . There 's room enough , though I have to sit nearly in the middle , else the boat wo n't trim , ''
`` Oh my Teddy ! Oh my Teddy ! ''
`` Oh , the dickens ! Now I 've done it , ''
`` Yes , please , but I never will again , ''
`` A characteristic , but not exactly complimentary , congratulation , ''
`` How good it sounds to hear you say ` Teddy ' ! No one ever calls me that but you , ''
`` Do n't I look like a married man and the head of a family ? ''
`` Now really , Jo , you ought to treat me with more respect , ''
`` Well , I did it to please Amy , ''
`` Now she 's beginning to marm it . Is n't it jolly to hear her ? ''
`` Not always , ''

`` We wanted to surprise you . We thought we were coming directly home , at first , but the dear old gentleman , as soon as we were married , found he could n't be ready under a month , at least , and sent us off to spend our honeymoon wherever we liked . Amy had once called Valrosa a regular honeymoon home , so we went there , and were as happy as people are but once in their lives . My faith ! Was n't it love among the roses ! ''

`` Jo , dear , I want to say one thing , and then we 'll put it by forever . As I told you in my letter when I wrote that Amy had been so kind to me , I never shall stop loving you , but the love is altered , and I have learned to see that it is better as it is . Amy and you changed places in my heart , that 's all . I think it was meant to be so , and would have come about naturally , if I had waited , as you tried to make me , but I never could be patient , and so I got a heartache . I was a boy then , headstrong and violent , and it took a hard lesson to show me my mistake . For it was one , Jo , as you said , and I found it out , after making a fool of myself . Upon my word , I was so tumbled up in my mind , at one time , that I did n't know which I loved best , you or Amy , and tried to love you both alike . But I could n't , and when I saw her in Switzerland , everything seemed to clear up all at once . You both got into your right places , and I felt sure that it was well off with the old love before it was on with the new , that I could honestly share my heart between sister Jo and wife Amy , and love them dearly . Will you believe it , and go back to the happy old times when we first knew one another ? ''

`` I 'll believe it , with all my heart , but , Teddy , we never can be boy and girl again . The happy old times ca n't come back , and we must n't expect it . We are man and woman now , with sober work to do , for playtime is over , and we must give up frolicking . I 'm sure you feel this . I see the change in you , and you 'll find it in me . I shall miss my boy , but I shall love the man as much , and admire him more , because he means to be what I hoped he would . We ca n't be little playmates any longer , but we will be brother and sister , to love and help one another all our lives , wo n't we , Laurie ? ''

`` As one of the children is older than yourself , you need n't talk so like a grandma . I flatter myself I 'm a ` gentleman growed ' as Peggotty said of David , and when you see Amy , you 'll find her rather a precocious infant , ''

`` Poor Jo ! We left you to bear it alone , while we went pleasuring . You are older . Here 's a line , and there 's another . Unless you smile , your eyes look sad , and when I touched the cushion , just now , I found a tear on it . You 've had a great deal to bear , and had to bear it all alone . What a selfish beast I 've been ! ''
`` You never shall be again , ''
`` high and mighty ''
`` Amy is too well-bred for that , and I am not the sort of man to submit to it . My wife and I respect ourselves and one another too much ever to tyrannize or quarrel . ''
`` She can blow him up as well as shine on him , ''
`` I look as if I needed it , do n't I ? ''
`` Play something , Amy . Let them hear how much you have improved , ''
`` My wife and I are very glad to meet you , sir . Please remember that there is always a welcome waiting for you over the way . ''
`` I too shall go , but I shall gladly come again , if you will gif me leave , dear madame , for a little business in the city will keep me here some days . ''
`` And Amy , what is she going to do ? ''

`` After doing the civil all round , and airing our best bonnet , we shall astonish you by the elegant hospitalities of our mansion , the brilliant society we shall draw about us , and the beneficial influence we shall exert over the world at large . That 's about it , is n't it , Madame Recamier ? ''

`` Am I an idiot and a brute ? How could I think so , when you refused a richer man for me , and wo n't let me give you half I want to now , when I have the right ? Girls do it every day , poor things , and are taught to think it is their only salvation , but you had better lessons , and though I trembled for you at one time , I was not disappointed , for the daughter was true to the mother 's teaching . I told Mamma so yesterday , and she looked as glad and grateful as if I 'd given her a check for a million , to be spent in charity . You are not listening to my moral remarks , Mrs. Laurence , ''
`` I wish we could do something for that capital old Professor . Could n't we invent a rich relation , who shall obligingly die out there in Germany , and leave him a tidy little fortune ? ''
`` And so you shall , like an angel as you are ! ''
`` It 's a fine old place , and will bring a handsome sum , for of course you intend to sell it , ''
`` That 's a truly Joian plan for you ! Is n't that just like her ? ''
`` She is putting on airs already , ''
`` I 'll testify that you tried to do it , ''

`` And I 've succeeded beyond my hopes , for here you are , a steady , sensible businessman , doing heaps of good with your money , and laying up the blessings of the poor , instead of dollars . But you are not merely a businessman , you love good and beautiful things , enjoy them yourself , and let others go halves , as you always did in the old times . I am proud of you , Teddy , for you get better every year , and everyone feels it , though you wo n't let them say so . Yes , and when I have my flock , I 'll just point to you , and say ` There 's your model , my lads ' . ''
`` I say , Jo , that 's rather too much , ''

`` You have all done more for me than I can ever thank you for , except by doing my best not to disappoint you . You have rather cast me off lately , Jo , but I 've had the best of help , nevertheless . So , if I 've got on at all , you may thank these two for it , ''
`` Oh , really , I beg pardon . It 's an uncommonly fine one , is n't it ? ''
`` Are you going to help about the fair , dear ? ''
`` Do you speak French , dear ? ''
`` Now I understand it all -- the child has been pining for young Laurence . Bless my heart , I never thought of such a thing ! ''
`` I do n't believe it , boys will be boys , young men must sow their wild oats , and women must not expect miracles . ''

`` One person begins a story , any nonsense you like , and tells as long as he pleases , only taking care to stop short at some exciting point , when the next takes it up and does the same . It 's very funny when well done , and makes a perfect jumble of tragical comical stuff to laugh over . Please start it , Mr. Brooke , ''
`` A ravishingly lovely lady , who exclaimed , with a cry of rapture , ` At last ! At last ! ' ''
`` Mademoiselle is charmante , tres jolie , is she not ? ''
`` I say , is n't bread ` riz ' enough when it runs over the pans ? ''
`` a much , and greatly laughed , and the master bid her throw away all the sweet stuff , and hide the pots . ''
`` Well , I call that plucky ! ''
`` To hear is to obey , but March is fairer far than May , ''

`` You are not made wise by experience , I hope ? ''
`` You 've got a treasure , young man , see that you deserve it . ''
`` Could you spare me some of your cake ? I really need some , I have so much company , and I ca n't make such delicious stuff as yours , ''

`` I would n't leave a word out of it . You 'll spoil it if you do , for the interest of the story is more in the minds than in the actions of the people , and it will be all a muddle if you do n't explain as you go on , ''

`` My husband shall always feel free to bring a friend home whenever he likes . I shall always be prepared . There shall be no flurry , no scolding , no discomfort , but a neat house , a cheerful wife , and a good dinner . John , dear , never stop to ask my leave , invite whom you please , and be sure of a welcome from me . ''
`` You ought to have sent word , or told me this morning , and you ought to have remembered how busy I was , ''
`` I had n't time to cook anything . I meant to dine at Mother 's . I 'm sorry , but I was so busy , ''

`` You must get yourself out of the scrape as you can . I 'm too used up to ` exert ' myself for anyone . It 's like a man to propose a bone and vulgar bread and cheese for company . I wo n't have anything of the sort in my house . Take that Scott up to Mother 's , and tell him I 'm away , sick , dead , anything . I wo n't see him , and you two can laugh at me and my jelly as much as you like . You wo n't have anything else here . ''
`` I 've no objection , ''
`` Oh , dear , ''
`` married life is very trying , and does need infinite patience as well as love , as Mother says . ''

`` John is a good man , but he has his faults , and you must learn to see and bear with them , remembering your own . He is very decided , but never will be obstinate , if you reason kindly , not oppose impatiently . He is very accurate , and particular about the truth -- a good trait , though you call him ` fussy ' . Never deceive him by look or word , Meg , and he will give you the confidence you deserve , the support you need . He has a temper , not like ours -- one flash and then all over -- but the white , still anger that is seldom stirred , but once kindled is hard to quench . Be careful , be very careful , not to wake his anger against yourself , for peace and happiness depend on keeping his respect . Watch yourself , be the first to ask pardon if you both err , and guard against the little piques , misunderstandings , and hasty words that often pave the way for bitter sorrow and regret . ''
`` I 'll take it , ''
`` You have n't seen my private expense book yet . ''

`` John , dear , I 'm ashamed to show you my book , for I 've really been dreadfully extravagant lately . I go about so much I must have things , you know , and Sallie advised my getting it , so I did , and my New Year 's money will partly pay for it , but I was sorry after I had done it , for I knew you 'd think it wrong in me . ''
`` Oh , what will he say when he comes to that awful fifty dollars ! ''
`` It 's worse than boots , it 's a silk dress , ''
`` It is n't made or trimmed , ''
`` Indeed I will ! Speak to me as if I were little Meg again . I often feel as if I needed teaching more than ever since these babies look to me for everything . ''

`` He tried not to be selfish , but he has felt rather forlorn , I fancy . This is just the time , Meg , when young married people are apt to grow apart , and the very time when they ought to be most together , for the first tenderness soon wears off , unless care is taken to preserve it . And no time is so beautiful and precious to parents as the first years of the little lives given to them to train . Do n't let John be a stranger to the babies , for they will do more to keep him safe and happy in this world of trial and temptation than anything else , and through them you will learn to know and love one another as you should . Now , dear , good-by . Think over Mother 's preachment , act upon it if it seems good , and God bless you all . ''
`` Will Demi lie still like a good boy , while Mamma runs down and gives poor Papa his tea ? ''
`` Ditto , ditto , Mr. Brooke , ''
`` It 's that naughty boy . I told him to go to sleep alone , and here he is , downstairs , getting his death a-cold pattering over that canvas , ''
`` If you told him to stay up there , and go to sleep alone , make him do it , or he will never learn to mind you . ''
`` Yes , of course . Come , Demi , ''
`` Let me stay with him , he 'll be good now , John . ''
`` But he 'll cry himself sick , ''
`` Certainly . Demi , say good night to Mamma , and let her go and rest , for she is very tired with taking care of you all day . ''
`` I never need fear that John will be too harsh with my babies . He does know how to manage them , and will be a great help , for Demi is getting too much for me . ''
`` These bits of lace are fastened under the chin with a rosebud , so , ''
`` It is always so quiet and pleasant here , it does me good , Meg , ''
`` Now you have been good children , and I 'll play anything you like , ''
`` It will be an immense care for Jo , ''

`` My castle was the most nearly realized of all . I asked for splendid things , to be sure , but in my heart I knew I should be satisfied , if I had a little home , and John , and some dear children like these . I 've got them all , thank God , and am the happiest woman in the world , ''
`` A large sheaf , but I know there 's room in your heart for it , Marmee dear , ''
`` Time for lunch , ''
`` So the poor knight is to be left sticking in the hedge , is he ? ''
`` Young ladies in America love independence as much as their ancestors did , and are admired and respected for supporting themselves . ''
`` Did the German song suit , Miss March ? ''
`` Try a little now . Here is Schiller 's Mary Stuart and a tutor who loves to teach . ''
`` Very well indeed ! ''
`` Tutors also have rather a hard time of it there , as I know to my sorrow . There 's no place like America for us workers , Miss Margaret . ''
`` I think you would if you had Laurie for a pupil . I shall be very sorry to lose him next year , ''
`` I have neither , and very few friends to care whether I live or die , ''
`` Thank you , that sounds pleasant , ''
`` I quite agree with you , ''
`` I 'm very sorry to hear of this , Miss March , ''
`` I do n't see how they can help it , ''
`` I 'll never tell him to my dying day , wild horses sha n't drag it out of me , so you 'll forgive me , Meg , and I 'll do anything to show how out-and-out sorry I am , ''
`` Good afternoon . I came to get my umbrella , that is , to see how your father finds himself today , ''
`` Do n't go . Are you afraid of me , Margaret ? ''
`` Shall I tell you how ? ''
`` I wo n't trouble you . I only want to know if you care for me a little , Meg . I love you so much , dear , ''
`` Will you try and find out ? I want to know so much , for I ca n't go to work with any heart until I learn whether I am to have my reward in the end or not . ''
`` Do you really mean that ? ''
`` I could n't help hearing , Meg . Thank you for defending me , and Aunt March for proving that you do care for me a little bit . ''
`` I hope the third year from this will end better . I mean it shall , if I live to work out my plans , ''
`` Much obliged for that recommendation . I take it as a good omen for the future and invite you to my wedding on the spot , ''
`` Thank you , ''
`` Opy doy . Me 's tummin ! ''
`` What ho , minion ! I need thee ! ''
`` We 've got Father and Mother , and each other , ''
`` I planned to spend mine in new music , ''
`` It 's naughty to fret , but I do think washing dishes and keeping things tidy is the worst work in the world . It makes me cross , and my hands get so stiff , I ca n't practice well at all . ''
`` Birds in their little nests agree , ''
`` Poor Jo ! It 's too bad , but it ca n't be helped . So you must try to be contented with making your name boyish , and playing brother to us girls , ''
`` If Jo is a tomboy and Amy a goose , what am I , please ? ''
`` I thought I 'd get her some with my dollar , ''
`` I 'll tell you what we 'll do , ''
`` let 's each get her something for Christmas , and not get anything for ourselves . ''
`` Some handkerchiefs , all hemmed , ''

`` I used to be so frightened when it was my turn to sit in the chair with the crown on , and see you all come marching round to give the presents , with a kiss . I liked the things and the kisses , but it was dreadful to have you sit looking at me while I opened the bundles , ''
`` I do n't see how you can write and act such splendid things , Jo . You 're a regular Shakespeare ! ''
`` When will he come home , Marmee ? ''
`` Yes , I have . Mine is dishes and dusters , and envying girls with nice pianos , and being afraid of people . ''
`` How good Meg is ! Come , Amy , let 's do as they do . I 'll help you with the hard words , and they 'll explain things if we do n't understand , ''
`` How nice my handkerchiefs look , do n't they ? Hannah washed and ironed them for me , and I marked them all myself , ''
`` Is n't that right ? I thought it was better to do it so , because Meg 's initials are M.M. , and I do n't want anyone to use these but Marmee , ''
`` May I go and help carry the things to the poor little children ? ''
`` Santa Claus , ''
`` They are lovely . But Beth 's roses are sweeter to me , ''
`` I wish I could send my bunch to Father . I 'm afraid he is n't having such a merry Christmas as we are . ''
`` Ought they to smoke like that ? ''
`` So do I , it was so smooth and pretty . But it will soon grow out again , ''
`` I hope you 'll have a good night , my poor dear . ''
`` I saw something I liked this morning , and I meant to tell it at dinner , but I forgot , ''

`` When I went to get some oysters for Hannah , Mr. Laurence was in the fish shop , but he did n't see me , for I kept behind the fish barrel , and he was busy with Mr. Cutter the fish-man . A poor woman came in with a pail and a mop , and asked Mr. Cutter if he would let her do some scrubbing for a bit of fish , because she had n't any dinner for her children , and had been disappointed of a day 's work . Mr. Cutter was in a hurry and said ` No ' , rather crossly , so she was going away , looking hungry and sorry , when Mr. Laurence hooked up a big fish with the crooked end of his cane and held it out to her . She was so glad and surprised she took it right into her arms , and thanked him over and over . He told her to ` go along and cook it ' , and she hurried off , so happy ! Was n't it good of him ? Oh , she did look so funny , hugging the big , slippery fish , and hoping Mr. Laurence 's bed in heaven would be ` aisy ' . ''

`` As I sat cutting out blue flannel jackets today at the rooms , I felt very anxious about Father , and thought how lonely and helpless we should be , if anything happened to him . It was not a wise thing to do , but I kept on worrying till an old man came in with an order for some clothes . He sat down near me , and I began to talk to him , for he looked poor and tired and anxious . ''
`` I like that kind of sermon . It 's the sort Father used to tell us , ''
`` That boy is suffering for society and fun , ''
`` Here I am , bag and baggage , ''

`` Mother sent her love , and was glad if I could do anything for you . Meg wanted me to bring some of her blanc mange , she makes it very nicely , and Beth thought her cats would be comforting . I knew you 'd laugh at them , but I could n't refuse , she was so anxious to do something . ''
`` I was thinking about our ' _ Pilgrim 's Progress _ ' , ''
`` Please , tell the young ladies what I say , and if they do n't care to come , why , never mind . ''
`` Oh sir , they do care , very very much ! ''
`` I 'm Beth . I love it dearly , and I 'll come , if you are quite sure nobody will hear me , and be disturbed , ''
`` How kind you are , sir ! ''
`` Mother , I 'm going to work Mr. Laurence a pair of slippers . He is so kind to me , I must thank him , and I do n't know any other way . Can I do it ? ''
`` Yes , dear . It will please him very much , and be a nice way of thanking him . The girls will help you about them , and I will pay for the making up , ''
`` Look there ! Look there ! ''
`` Miss Elizabeth March . ''
`` For me ? ''
`` You read it ! I ca n't , I feel so queer ! Oh , it is too lovely ! ''
`` come in ! ''
`` I wish I 'd known that nice girl . Maybe she would have helped me , I 'm so stupid , ''
`` And such lovely weather , I 'm so glad of that , ''
`` You said the other day that you 'd be perfectly happy if you could only go to Annie Moffat 's , ''
`` Yes ; we ought to do it , even if we are afraid . I say he may come , and his grandpa , too , if he likes . ''
`` Poor old Jo ! She came in looking as if bears were after her , ''
`` It 's all my fault , I forgot him , there is n't a seed or a drop left . Oh , Pip ! Oh , Pip ! How could I be so cruel to you ? ''

`` He 's been starved , and he sha n't be baked now he 's dead . I 'll make him a shroud , and he shall be buried in the garden , and I 'll never have another bird , never , my Pip ! for I am too bad to own one , ''
`` It ca n't seem so without Marmee and little Pip , ''
`` Here 's Mother , dear , and you shall have another bird tomorrow , if you want it . ''
`` Are you satisfied with your experiment , girls , or do you want another week of it ? ''
`` I 'll do my lessons every day , and not spend so much time with my music and dolls . I am a stupid thing , and ought to be studying , not playing , ''
`` Miss Meg March , one letter and a glove , ''
`` Two letters for Doctor Jo , a book , and a funny old hat , which covered the whole post office and stuck outside , ''
`` And I got a note from Mr. Laurence , asking me to come over and play to him tonight , before the lamps are lighted , and I shall go , ''
`` Your deer are much prettier than our ugly buffaloes , ''
`` I guess he 'll like it , ''
`` No , I did . I wanted to amuse him one night when you were all away , and he was rather dismal . He did like it , so do n't scold , Jo , ''

`` Jo talks about the country where we hope to live sometime -- the real country , she means , with pigs and chickens and haymaking . It would be nice , but I wish the beautiful country up there was real , and we could ever go to it , ''

`` If people really want to go , and really try all their lives , I think they will get in , for I do n't believe there are any locks on that door or any guards at the gate . I always imagine it is as it is in the picture , where the shining ones stretch out their hands to welcome poor Christian as he comes up from the river . ''
`` Mine is to stay at home safe with Father and Mother , and help take care of the family , ''
`` I hope she wo n't . She is so funny and dear as she is , ''
`` What 's the name ? ''
`` Who wrote it ? ''
`` I knew it ! I knew it ! Oh , my Jo , I am so proud ! ''
`` If something very pleasant should happen now , we should think it a delightful month , ''
`` Two pleasant things are going to happen right away . Marmee is coming down the street , and Laurie is tramping through the garden as if he had something nice to tell . ''
`` I do n't see how you dared to do it , ''
`` Come girls . ''
`` Hannah will tell us what to do , and we 'll have everything nice when you come home , ''
`` Meg , I wish you 'd go and see the Hummels . You know Mother told us not to forget them . ''
`` Ca n't you , Jo ? ''

`` I have been every day , but the baby is sick , and I do n't know what to do for it . Mrs. Hummel goes away to work , and Lottchen takes care of it . But it gets sicker and sicker , and I think you or Hannah ought to go . ''
`` My head aches and I 'm tired , so I thought maybe some of you would go , ''
`` You 've had the scarlet fever , have n't you ? ''
`` Mrs. Hummel 's . It died in my lap before she got home , ''

`` Do n't be frightened , I guess I sha n't have it badly . I looked in Mother 's book , and saw that it begins with headache , sore throat , and queer feelings like mine , so I did take some belladonna , and I feel better , ''

`` You 've been over the baby every day for more than a week , and among the others who are going to have it , so I 'm afraid you are going to have it , Beth . I 'll call Hannah , she knows all about sickness . ''
`` Do n't let Amy come . She never had it , and I should hate to give it to her . Ca n't you and Meg have it over again ? ''

`` we will have Dr. Bangs , just to take a look at you , dear , and see that we start right . Then we 'll send Amy off to Aunt March 's for a spell , to keep her out of harm 's way , and one of you girls can stay at home and amuse Beth for a day or two . ''
`` Jo , please . ''
`` Water ! ''
`` The fever 's turned , she 's sleepin ' nat ` ral , her skin 's damp , and she breathes easy . Praise be given ! Oh , my goodness me ! ''
`` I 'm so full of happiness , that if Father was only here , I could n't hold one drop more , ''
`` I 'm glad it 's over , because we 've got you back , ''
`` What about Jo ? Please say something nice , for she has tried so hard and been so very , very good to me , ''

`` I read in _ Pilgrim 's Progress _ today how , after many troubles , Christian and Hopeful came to a pleasant green meadow where lilies bloomed all year round , and there they rested happily , as we do now , before they went on to their journey 's end , ''
`` Are you satisfied ? Does it seem like home , and do you feel as if you should be happy here ? ''
`` What 's the last joke ? Undo the bundle and see , Meg , ''

`` I shall come every day , Father , and expect to keep my old place in all your hearts , though I am married . Beth is going to be with me a great deal , and the other girls will drop in now and then to laugh at my housekeeping struggles . Thank you all for my happy wedding day . Good-by , good-by ! ''
`` Hannah left it on the kitchen table a minute , and the kittens got at it . I 'm very sorry , Amy , ''
`` Miss Eliott is a very sweet girl , and seemed to enjoy herself , I thought , ''
`` I should so like to see it printed soon , ''

`` Yes , we all do , and love her for being so ready to forgive . It must have been dreadfully hard , after working so long and setting your heart on selling your own pretty things . I do n't believe I could have done it as kindly as you did , ''
`` Jo , dear , I 'm very selfish , but I could n't spare you , and I 'm glad you are not going quite yet , ''
`` All serene ! Coming in tonight . ''
`` Mercy on me , Beth loves Laurie ! ''
`` What is it , dear ? ''
`` I thought you were asleep , ''
`` No , it 's a new one , but I can bear it , ''
`` You ca n't , there is no cure . ''
`` Does anything trouble you , deary ? ''
`` Go to sleep , dear . I 'll stay with you . ''
`` One thing I leave in your especial care , ''
`` You mean your papers ? ''
`` I 'll do my best , for your sake , ''

`` Now I must go and prepare Mr. Laurence to be very kind to my poor boy . I wish he 'd love Beth , perhaps he may in time , but I begin to think I was mistaken about her . Oh dear ! How can girls like to have lovers and refuse them ? I think it 's dreadful . ''
`` Jo , dear , I 'm glad you know it . I 've tried to tell you , but I could n't . ''
`` Why , Jo , how could I , when he was so fond of you ? ''
`` You 'll tell them this when we go home ? ''

`` I do n't know how to express myself , and should n't try to anyone but you , because I ca n't speak out except to my Jo . I only mean to say that I have a feeling that it never was intended I should live long . I 'm not like the rest of you . I never made any plans about what I 'd do when I grew up . I never thought of being married , as you all did . I could n't seem to imagine myself anything but stupid little Beth , trotting about at home , of no use anywhere but there . I never wanted to go away , and the hard part now is the leaving you all . I 'm not afraid , but it seems as if I should be homesick for you even in heaven . ''
`` How beautiful this is ! ''
`` I feel stronger when you are here . ''
`` Poor Jo ! She 's fast asleep , so I wo n't wake her to ask leave . She shows me all her things , and I do n't think she 'll mind if I look at this ''
`` Oh , Beth , come back ! Come back ! ''
`` Be happy . I am here . ''
`` Dis is mine effalunt ! ''

`` Young ladies , you remember what I said to you a week ago . I am sorry this has happened , but I never allow my rules to be infringed , and I never break my word . Miss March , hold out your hand . ''
`` You will now stand on the platform till recess , ''
`` You can go , Miss March , ''
`` Yankees are a deal the most tricky , everybody knows . There you go ! ''
`` By George , it 's all up with us ! Goodbye , Kate . Miss Jo owes me one , so you are finished , ''
`` What is it ? ''
`` Which do you like best ? ''
`` Try again . Truth is n't a bad game , ''
`` What is your greatest fault ? ''
`` Now my turn , ''
`` What do you hate most ? ''
`` I was sure she would think better of it . Poor old fellow ! I 've been through it all , and I can sympathize . ''

`` That is perfectly natural , and quite harmless , if the liking does not become a passion and lead one to do foolish or unmaidenly things . Learn to know and value the praise which is worth having , and to excite the admiration of excellent people by being modest as well as pretty , Meg . ''

`` After I 'd seen as much of the world as I want to , I 'd like to settle in Germany and have just as much music as I choose . I 'm to be a famous musician myself , and all creation is to rush to hear me . And I 'm never to be bothered about money or business , but just enjoy myself and live for what I like . That 's my favorite castle . What 's yours , Meg ? ''

`` I should like a lovely house , full of all sorts of luxurious things -- nice food , pretty clothes , handsome furniture , pleasant people , and heaps of money . I am to be mistress of it , and manage it as I like , with plenty of servants , so I never need work a bit . How I should enjoy it ! For I would n't be idle , but do good , and make everyone love me dearly . ''
`` November is the most disagreeable month in the whole year , ''
`` Ah ! I see him now , it is that imp Tina who makes me a fool with my cap . Well , it is nothing , but see you , if this lesson goes not well , you too shall wear him . ''
`` I wish these papers did not come in the house . They are not for children to see , nor young people to read . It is not well , and I haf no patience with those who make this harm . ''

`` There is a demand for whisky , but I think you and I do not care to sell it . If the respectable people knew what harm they did , they would not feel that the living was honest . They haf no right to put poison in the sugarplum , and let the small ones eat it . No , they should think a little , and sweep mud in the street before they do this thing . ''
`` Going home ? Ah , you are happy that you haf a home to go in , ''
`` What have you been at today , bubchen ? ''
`` Prut ! Thou beginnest early . What did the little Mary say to that ? ''
`` Thou shouldst save some for the little friend . Sweets to the sweet , mannling , ''
`` Do great boys like great girls , to , ` Fessor ? ''
`` I 'm shopping . ''
`` You haf no umbrella . May I go also , and take for you the bundles ? ''
`` Here 's the place for my errands . Will you come in ? It wo n't take long . ''
`` Should we no do a little what you call shopping for the babies , and haf a farewell feast tonight if I go for my last call at your so pleasant home ? ''
`` May they haf oranges and figs ? ''
`` Heart 's dearest , why do you cry ? ''
`` Ach , mein Gott , that is so good ! ''

`` Jo , I haf nothing but much love to gif you . I came to see if you could care for it , and I waited to be sure that I was something more than a friend . Am I ? Can you make a little place in your heart for old Fritz ? ''
`` Jove-like ''
`` Sentimental ? Yes . Thank Gott , we Germans believe in sentiment , and keep ourselves young mit it . Your English ` you ' is so cold , say ` thou ' , heart 's dearest , it means so much to me , ''
`` This , ''
`` Let it go , it has done its duty , and I will haf a fresh one when I read all the brown book in which she keeps her little secrets , ''

`` I read that , and I think to myself , She has a sorrow , she is lonely , she would find comfort in true love . I haf a heart full , full for her . Shall I not go and say , ` If this is not too poor a thing to gif for what I shall hope to receive , take it in Gott 's name ? ' ''
`` I had no courage to think that at first , heavenly kind as was your welcome to me . But soon I began to hope , and then I said , ' I will haf her if I die for it , ' and so I will ! ''
`` Me has tea ! ''
`` Mornin ' now , ''
`` Go ` way , me do n't love Parpar . ''
`` I 'll weep a little weep when I go to bed . It wo n't do to be dismal now . ''
`` Does I ? ''
`` Yes , but I ca n't show you how , for it is done when we do n't see . ''
`` I dess Dod does it when I 's asleep . ''
`` Truly , Marmar ? ''
`` Then we 'll go and eat up all the raisins . ''
`` I kissed her , ''
`` Oh , she liked it , and she kissed me , and I liked it . Do n't little boys like little girls ? ''

`` Are n't you company too ? I thought she 'd suit Brooke , but he keeps talking to Meg , and Kate just stares at them through that ridiculous glass of hers . I 'm going , so you need n't try to preach propriety , for you ca n't do it , Jo . ''
`` Why do n't you learn ? I should think you had taste and talent for it , ''
`` Oh , indeed ! ''
`` Dear me , how dreadful ! ''

`` Oh , yes , of course it 's very nice and proper in them to do so . We have many most respectable and worthy young women who do the same and are employed by the nobility , because , being the daughters of gentlemen , they are both well bred and accomplished , you know , ''
`` Do n't you read German ? ''
`` I 'll read a bit to encourage you . ''
`` You 've a nice accent and in time will be a clever reader . I advise you to learn , for German is a valuable accomplishment to teachers . I must look after Grace , she is romping . ''
`` I did n't come to chaperone a governess , though she is young and pretty . What odd people these Yankees are . I 'm afraid Laurie will be quite spoiled among them . ''
`` In spite of their demonstrative manners , American girls are very nice when one knows them . ''
`` You can put your own things on your own table , if you prefer , ''
